reviewText:
I've played for half and hour and I already feel like I never want to touch this again. The tutorial itself teaches you how to spend money.

Basically the game is designed around making the building as tedious as possible to entice the player to spend real money to skip absurd waiting times. I thought the '8 hours to collect wheat' must have been an exagguration but it's not. It's literally wait 8 hours or spend money.

The game isn't designed to be fun, it's designed to be tedious unless you spend money.

The battles are incredibly shallow. Three lanes of units move towards eachother without your control and you 'tap' them to 'charge' when prompted. You can tell archers to shoot (through a very cumbersome system that is clearly designed for your phone), and 'taunt' which is really the only way you can move between 'lanes'. It's utterly woeful.

Not to mention you can again, pay real money to buy better units and buff said units. You also need to spend money to heal units. And spend money to avoid more ridiculous waiting times to build more units.

Even on mobile phone, this game seems terrible. It's basically an excercise in tedium unless you pay money. They didn't want to make the game fun, rather they tried to make it as dull as possible unless you cough up money.

Avoid like the plague. This is an abomination of a game. Sega and Creative Assembly should be ashamed of themselves.

reviewText:
I have to admit, for the time being CA seems to be focused on casual enjoyment.

You'd think this was your total war game in small scale, instead you have a game that teaches your mom how to terraform.

This game isn't ''Bad'', It's fine if you're sitting in a waiting room with a tablet PC.

For a PC game, though, i have to say collecting wheat and watching timers count down is not a sufficient total war experience. I can't recommend playing this for any serious entertainment quality.

Edit: Also, all customization and speedups, do, as expected, cost a currency that you must buy with real money. (Or farm in-game for a geological amount of time)
http://cloud-4.steamusercontent.com/ugc/717537613784190996/5A68B5BFB5C8D876D505FEE5FBFA850937A25158/

P.S. When your English christian soldiers win they sometimes shout ''Praise be to the gods''
They all use the recycled Roman/Barbarian voices from Rome 2, and it's random, so Picts can have posh roman voices.

P.S.S. The militia spear unit is literally peasants with pitchforks, you can slay mailed knights with them, you can also charge and kill half a unit with archers if you get the perfect timing.

reviewText:
Get your blades sharpened, you arrow knocked and you pitchforks ready to go to war with the marketing team of Total War Battles: Kingdom! Like, seriously, wtf?!?

This game is terrible in how they are trying to market and profit from it. It is disgraceful to the Total War franchise and I have only played one other Total War game and that was Total War Battles: Shogun and that game was terrible but way better than this!

The entire game is based off of micro-transactions as you CANNOT do much without buying in-game platinum currency of Gold! Also, 8 hours to cut wood?!?!? I am here to play games, not be like, “I want to open my game, click on button, then close it and come back in 8 hours! :D” NO! Just no... *cry*

Don’t even think about this game. It is awesome that they are making a free-to-play Total War game and I appreciate it where the game itself is interesting and has the concepts of what I might enjoy like building and managing your own kingdom and the battle style system that I was kind of hoping for (and enjoyed to some extent in this game which I guess is a plus), but this was not what I was expecting nor want. Nice try though :/

reviewText:
I gave this game a good shot. Got to level 26 and was starting to gather materials for crafting units you have to normally pay gold for which you buy with real money. It was fun up until that point. The AI after awhile suddenly becomes nearly impossible to beat since they can have several elite units of the same type while you can only have one. And they will be higher rank than you can possibly achieve without throwing tons of money at the game specially with how fast you can level just trying to gather supplies that the missions will be beyond your troops capability of winning without you paying for buffs and gear and super troops bought from the store.

This unfortunately is too much pay to win for me to recommend.  I thought when I got to crafting that maybe hey I could just put some time into it and get the same items but with more time required. I gathered the materials for an item, hit craft, and saw that it said stage 1. Stage 1...So I have to gather the supplies FIVE times in order to build anything and if you don't use mastercraft you could end up making a pile of scrap metal instead of what you aimed to make. Mastercraft costs nearly triple the resources of basic craft.

Not to mention it takes 12-18 hours to craft one stage. And it takes 12 hours per sheep to get one hide or cows which will take 6 days to recover their land before you can butcher them again and you only get 2 after 20 hours of waiting for them to grow. So with three sheep farms you get 18 resources a day..And the most basic sword/armor/shield takes 25 to start stage one and thats using basic craft not master.

This is a disappointing game that I am sad I wasted even a couple days playing after seeing how much of a cash grab it really is. You disappoint me CA...You made my favorite games of my childhood and then you spit out this piece of crap and insult your fans like this. Definite hands down, don't waste your time or your money. Find something far better than this on your phone than a crap mobile game shoved into the pc world.

Damn..

reviewText:
To clarify, Total War Battles: KINGDOM, has nothing to do with Total War series. It is a well known brand, and that is the only reason why that name is being used here. Lets think about it, they could have released a game called Battles: KINGDOM, but everyone knows that by adding Total War in the name, it will get much more attention, and that will lead to much more people trying it.

As for me, Battles: KINGDOM, as that is how I will call this game, because it is a disgusting cheap trick to call it Total War, as was explained before by me, is nearly a copy of Stronghold: KINGDOMs. I do not think it is a coincidence. We start in England, oh wow, so cool and unexpected. Whole world is made out of hexes, that can be edited. Build a building or change them into something else, such as terrain modification. Buildings have their roles, which takes time to complete.

If You Ain't Talkin' Money I Don't Wanna Talk!

I think that pretty much sums it all up, whole game concept. If you do not want to wait, pay! That is what the game is all about.

Once I saw how the battle looks, I made a quadruple facepalm, with botfh of my hands, and feet, touching my forehead. There are three fixed lines, that unit is move on vertically, meaning they only move forward, like zombies. They ca not even be controlled, they can swap position with other unit though, at the horizontal level.

Burn it with fire!

I do not recommend.

reviewText:
Disadvantages:
1. The game seems to be purposely slow paced  (especially when it comes to equiping troops and leveling to 2nd rank), it's very likely for most to lose their patience and either buy gold or quit the game.
2. Nonsense restrictions, such as on crafting, which can be carried out only by one blacksmith at a time.
3. Gold buttons are everywhere, thus making it very likely to 'accidentally' spend even that little gold bars you got available from in-game leveling and battle quests.
4. Enemy AI on challenging and 'brutal' difficulty,  has often additional soldiers which do not appear on pre-battle info. In general it feels the AI is 'cheating' on certain battles.
5. The game is quite unbalanced when it comes to the gathering of resources. Insanely long cooldowns. As an example: gathering 20pcs of stone takes 2:30 hours... Upgrading structures consume an imposible amount of resources.
6. Crafting gear is expensive and exaustingly slow, it takes 5 crafting 'stages' and takes about 4 days to craft a simple bracelet.
7. There is no way to tell about the water level and flooding likeliness.
8. When I reached winter season, I found it so terribly boring, no crops and no forests. Trees yield way too little wood, by chopping 1500 pcs (first castle upgrade) you end up clearing everything around making the map desolate and cold, like Isenguard... Furthermore 'tracking beasts' on winter removes all the last (if any remained) forrest left on the now depressing looking map. In retrospective, I think I mismanaged awfully the resources, however it is actually not hard to do so and go off track.
9. The game fails to inform the player early on about building bonuses (forcing you around level 25-35 to demolish, rebuild and spent additional time and resources restructiring your cities). For example, I found out later in the game that you must build producers next to military buildings, it is rather vague how many residences you need to sustain a city and I had to count hexes to make out wood cutters range (tracking and wood cutting range is about 4-5 hexes).
10. Has some minor bugs and disconnects from server 2-3 times (on average) during a 6h period.

Advantages:
1. The game has very well polished graphics for a game of it's kind.
2. Battle and map zooms in, up to a great detail, very pleasant to the eye.
3. Terraforming (changing the flow of rivers etc) and the changing of seasons is quite nice.
4. Great variety of troops, however I'd like more detail on weaknesses and strengths of certain units.
5. I believe the game most probably might be much more playable on my tablet.

Conclusion:
There is lack of vital information about how things work and -alas- you got to discover them by yourself. It's very difficult to enjoy properly this game, you either must have got lots of time and patience or  spend a good deal of real cash. I'd prefer just paying a one time amount for it as a complete game, without the long resource 'cooldwns' and any other cash-involved transactions.

Suggestions :
Reduce the cost of construction and cooldowns, amplify the benefits of gamer commitment to the game. Alternatively give the posibility of a one time purchase into a 'premium' status (global reduced cooldowns, reduced crafting costs) with the guarantee of no more gold transactions.

Epilogue:
We choose to play a game in order to get entertained, enjoy some challenge and overall feel better at the end of the day. This game fails delivering such.

reviewText:
First of all we need to establish the premise that this game is not a total war game, nor will it ever be strictly a total war game. This game does have total war features but it reminds me of a cross between age of empires and game of war. Positives of this game include its terraforming system which you can change the hieght of land and change directions of water intuiteively. Customisation was also a nice feature being able to make your character but I would like there to be alot more. Battles were fun and I like the inclusion of missions, duels and soon to be a campaign. Graphics and animations are quite good for a mobile game and excelled from what I thought they would be like. I can imagine this game progressing and more features being added to make an already decent game a good game.

Now for the negative... I feel like alot of reviews expect this game to be like most Total Wars and if you have that outlook this game will disapoint you. This game is in beta and does not have all the features, it also lacks some polish and the game even crashed once for me and I noticed some bugs in the tutorial, but nothing major. This game also takes time to unlock things so dedication is needed to tend to crops, resources, buildings and missions. You can purchase gold (guys gotta make money somehow) but I don't like P2W, although this game does not seem like anything is unachievable by normal means, just takes a bit longer.

My Main gripe with this game is there is hardly any tactical depth compared to Total War, this was disapointing. This game is in BETA and it will get better, but if you do not like it now there is no point in getting it later. p.s narrator was annoying...

reviewText:
TOTAL WAIT FARMING : KINGDOM WONT COME

Originally i figured, a Total war game for free? Why not! It has to be fun.

God was i wrong.

The game is pretty good honestly, but its the crap you have to deal with that WILL annoy you.
So my DAY of game play (yes i played it that long) was awesome, i loved the game, but then came the 2nd day. I found that somehow my quarry flooded, and for half the day i was stuck with no quarry. Why am i complaining about that? Because i had earlier filled a dam that contained water that could leak into the quarry.... so the water magically broke the ground?


My 2nd problem is no tutorial. I mean come on, i deconstructed barracks thinking it was a permanent unit station, but nope, just disband it and your fine. But that's my stupidity, but aside from that, no In depth tutorial.


Now here comes the part that got me.



So my army was fine, my economy was starting to recover, so i used the lovely wallet warrior shop (Market) to buy stone to finish my 2nd knights barracks. i had planned on getting some more long sword knights, BUT AVAST MY EYES!
I CAN ONLY HAVE ONE UNIT OF LONG SWORD KNIGHTS? unless...  *GASP* I BUY ANOTHER ONE!

Good Game CA, but luckily my wallet is empty.

So on with that, AI army's can have more than 1 unit of long sword knights, and at the same time you can only have 1 medium cavalry unit? while AI can have 2?

Come on CA.....

I dont think these are the guys i remember making awesome games like R:TW, Barbarian Invasion (Still unfinished sadly) and Medieval 2.

reviewText:
What's the difference between Total War: Kingdom and Goat Simulator?
One is a complete and utter joke, the other is a game about goats.

TW:K Sucks so much. Firstly, I give it a go, a good go - I put in many hours to get a complete look at the game.

First of all - The resource system doesnt even work properly - you wait for several hours to collect wood, for instance, but you have to actually be online to collect it. It's not like its a proper streaming economy - this would be so much better. You buy a woodcutter - all your work should be done.

Secondly - The balance is ♥♥♥♥ing horrible - It's so obviously pay-to-win its excrutiatingly painful to play against other people. I muster the best units I can, with all the upgrades. I didn't purchase any gold so I couldnt recruit the most advanced units (which would cost 200 gold OR approximately 300 hours playtime to get 200 gold for free).
Moreover, No more rock-paper-scissors style Total War. Archers now beat cavalry in melee, spearmen beat swordsmen etc.

Thirdly - The battles are so damn boring. I mean, who thought this could be fun at all? There's also a lot of UI lag, which makes it hard for you to get 'Good' or 'Perfect' charges to any level of consistency. At times it runs like a jet-ski on gravel despite it being played on a high-end PC.

I know this is a seperate team of people from Creative Assembly and they may or may not have worked on previous titles, but I suggest that anyone in CA who has an ounce of goodwill in his body, kick these devs out of CA. But I guess I wait to wait 8 years for that to happen (or get it NOW for 500 gold!).

reviewText: I play World of Tanks, so I am familiar with free to play games. There are plenty of games that use free-to-play models well and are developed with a PC gaming audience in mind; LoL, DOTA, TF2, WoT. Generally the obstacle to progress in these games is an experience system locking out hightier or desirable items which you can unlock by playing the game, or alternatively they simply offer a cash shop with funny hats that people buy for reasons?!?!\n\nThis game is free to play of the mobile variety, so rather than making gameplay and fun" (insofar as world of tanks could be described as "fun") the route to unlocking things it instead uses your precious time
date: or your money. Or both.\nWhile time lockouts might make a bit of sense for games you'll play occasionally through the day on facebook or your phone/tablet
recommended: they make no damn sense in a PC port. There are also shameless paywalls for powerful units and unit upgrades.\n\nAlso the UI is a straight mobile port so it's got chunky
hoursPlayed:
mobile optimised UI elements.

tl;dr I have no idea why this even ended up on steam.

reviewText:
Keep in mind, this is a beta testing review!!!

So I have not played much of this game yet. I can say I was very excited about it when I first signed up and when I got my beta key. Now, well... not so much. The game itself is a lot like a mix between civilization and clash of clans with the battles being much like the total war battles: shogun except without all the buildings you can build in battle. So as a sequel to total war battles: shogun, it is ok. As a Total War game, I do not recommend it.

Positives:
Graphics and terraforming are pretty cool
The simple strategies may appeal to less serious strategy gamers
I enjoy building my town
The tutorial is helpful
Although they are simple, microbattles are pretty cool to see because each unit is fighting against individual enemies
Orders are cool as well as they give different bonuses to units and orders are attainable from churches
Not everything is pay to win as some things you cannot use gold to get
Login is good and not buggy (which tends to happen in many beta games)
I like the medieval feel of the game
There seems to be an unlimited amount of workers" or "builders" which is great!
The peasant and craftsman systems (your workers) seems useful.
I enjoy having to build multiple barracks and stables that each field one unit as this makes the town bigger and cooler-looking.

Negatives:
Fighting is too simple (see above positives)
Not at all what I expected from a total war game
More or less pay to win (strong units cost "gold"
date:
aka money) You can of course earn gold but it takes a very long time (I guess it makes sense because the game will be free so they need a way to make money)
Some buildings are not available until much later in the game
Upgrading buildings seems to take a lot of grinding and upgrading castles (main building) seems to require having multiple castles and towns and having a certain amount of buildings in your town.
I personally think that the lord (basically
recommended: you) should be more customizable as right now there are only a few different options for hair color
voteText: etc.\n\nSo overall this is a fun game although not at all what I expected or wanted to play from Total War

reviewText:
Total Waste and Boring: KINGDOM

I have never written a review for a game, but this one deserves one

I was part of the beta testing and really tried to play the game and expand
After 53.4 hrs and 5 regions with level3 Castles, game turned out to be a major battle grinder to level up my units so they don't suck. After a battle i had to wait for an average of 15 minutes for them to recover in order to reuse them again .... (or pay gold to insta-revive them). I decided enough is enough and uninstalled. Will never touch this game again.

The ammount of time you need to spend to actually do something in this game can be compared to smoking. Every 10-15 minutes you need to launch game to play a battle or harvest something and repeat that forever...
You need to calculate the 2-3 or 8 hour periods so you login and click stuff to collect because they need to be clicked....
So either you have no life and no other games to play, or you are rich and have cash to spend to play the game without wasting your time.
I don't even wanna talk about the combat system because i will spend 2 hours writing my complaints about how much it sucks.

1/10 It can fool you for some hours until you realize that it isn't worth your time

reviewText: I played the game in beta 2.0 and again in 3.0 (it reset the entire game so I had to build everything back up again).  It has terrible resource balance which forces constant market exchanges that are costly.  In battle, it is a classic 'pay to succeed' game.  You almost can't win some battles without buying specialized units.  You can craft these special units at the blacksmith but it is very costly and time consuming and at the end of it there is still a possibility 'you workers manage to make a pile of metal scraps' and you lose all the resources you put into and still don't get the unit (pretty much forcing you to buy the units if you want them).  The objectives are trying to encourage duels against live opponents but there are seldom live opponents to play against. The list of frustrations could go on and on with this game.  Bottom line is, if you want to succeed at this game be prepared to spend the $$$$$.

reviewText:
Hello steam subscribers I am here to write a review for this game. Before I get into the fighting ♥♥♥♥ spirit with this review I should tell you I am a long time Total War player and started with Shogun 1 when my balls first dropped and have played everything after that and enjoyed them thoroughly (although some more than others). Since the series has been around so long players have come to expect a certain type of game when they see the total war logo with the tiny samurai horseman logo next to the letter, you know the one I'm talking aboot ;)

WHAT IS DIFFERENT?

This game for all intents and purposes is NOT a total war game, there is no turn based campaign map instead it is real time much like a command&conquer where buildings need time to finish contructing. While there are real time tactical battles, the open ended and diverse battle maps known from the other total war titles are gone as well. This means there are no terrain advantages or disadvantages (at least I have found) during battles and the battlefield is made up of 3 lanes.

+WHAT IS BATTLE?+

Each lane has 3 slots for units, and I will illustrate how you may distribute your units among these slots by making a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ diagram with text and little symbols here

front<- [ Infantry, Cavalry, and Ranged ] [ Infantry, Cavalry, and Ranged ] [ Infantry, Cavalry, Ranged, and Siege Weapon ]
front<- [ Infantry, Cavalry, and Ranged ] [ Infantry, Cavalry, and Ranged ] [ Siege Weapon ]
front<- [ Infantry, Cavalry, and Ranged ] [ Infantry, Cavalry, and Ranged ] [ Infantry, Cavalry, Ranged, and Siege Weapon ]

As you can maybe see there is SOME depth to battles, but the meat of battles and how they are decided is military orders and unit abilities and the traditional rock paper scissors gameplay of other TW tittles. And yes, I spelled titles that way on purpose. After your units gain enough experience they can unlock special abilities with a variety of effects depending ont he unit type. Each unti has 2 choices for ability. Military orders are like general abilities but you are able to use them throughout the whole battle but they have a timer cooldown between each use, unliek unit abilities which can only be used once. So troop choice is extremely important in battles and the right combination of orders and abilities.

+WHAT IS CAMPAIGN?+

The campaign map is layed out before you like a giant deep dish pizza pie on hexagonal tiles. You can build buildings, gather the resources which are silver, stone, food, and wood *INSERT STRONGHOLD Wood Needed" VOICE CLIP HERE*. I'm pretty sick of writing this review already so I'm going to wrap it up with the big important thign about this game.

+WHAT IS LOVE?+

This game screams IPHONE WINDOWS TABLET TIME SINK. And like most other tablet time sink the pace of this game  is extremely slowwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwwww. BUT: and this is where the magic happens; you can purchase a 5th resource known as gold and with this gold you can speed up harvesting
recommended: and purchase unique battlefield buffs such as flaming arrows and saxon mercenaries. But to be fair and ubjective you can acquire these things without payign gold
hoursPlayed:
but much much slower. So slow that if you go in expecting this game to be as fast as traditional TW games you will be angry and write angry reviews containing 1 sentence referencing pop culture memes.

+BABY DONT HURT ME+

All in all I WOULD reccomend this as a game you can hop into and SLOWELY develop your realm and then exit and do other stuff

reviewText:
Most humble and greatest review for a game, which is the result of miscarriage
Remember those browser games, where you build stuff, farm stuff, destroy other people's stuff and steal all their resources so you can repeat this again? Generally they are all the same. You can pay some extra bucks there to get extra income of in-game resources, finish construction of virtually same buildings instantly with a level number increasing next to their name somewhere, so you can spend another 10 minutes of your pathetic life playing a game that's not fun but you can at least ruin other people's fun?

This game tries to be something like that. I'm thinking so the very least, in a way when that awkward guy you have as an acquaintance does something strange, you try to be polite and not make fun of him. Which I'm not trying to be, as this game is not my ♥♥♥♥ing acquaintance and it sucks major ♥♥♥♥♥. Almost literally.

Okay, so here we have it. A F2P game with Total War in its name. A major AAA title you don't even have to pay for. Let's get to the gameplay!

You are the lord of some Britbong duchy/county whatever, turns out something happened to your daddy and some old regent dude is giving you a tutorial of doing things, which he was too wasted to do. You build a dam, which is the coolest ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ part of the game, because there are water physics (!) then you get praised for clicking on something. Surely increased my self-worth.

Oh, and about clicking: you only need to use the left mouse button. Right click does nothing, it would be too hardcore for the game. It's obvious this was made with touchscreen in the mind.

Anyway, from first glance it looks fairly average but it gets worse: you need two hours to saturate a resource tile which gives you 20 wood/food/something or you can click on harvest all button, which does it for all the tiles eight hours and nets you half that much per tile. And the best part is: you need to manually collect all collected things by clicking on them. Then wait for it to grow out again. Which won't start until you collect the resources. Then once it grew out, you need to order them to start saturating it again. So much fun to be had! But wait, it gets even better: if you pay money, you don't even need to wait for all this fun, it happens instantly! And you should pay, because getting 10 resources is not even nearly enough, you need about 100 to build the silliest of buildings. Then upgrading it, of course, which costs even more.

That's about the management part, but worry not, there is  COMBAT  like in every proper game! And it even gets you resources, so you can have more fun faster! But not so fast. First the concept: there are different units, which is the gathering of soldiers. A battlefield can hold 9 units on each side. To create a unit, you need to build a corresponding building, which gives you one unit of the type you want. There are barracks, archery ranges and stables, for starters. When a building is finished, you are asked to pick one of 4 possible units to be linked to the building. Too bad, two of them are more powerful and you can only buy them for real money, so get your wallet ready! More advanced barracks housing knights are avalaible later in the game but I don't think a living human being played this game long enough to get that far. One unit consists about 16-18 men, so that's about 150 dudes fighting against 150 other, assuming there are no siege engines shooting an army, because they are substracted from the lineup and are shooting offscreen. This is the Originally posted by Store Page: Large scale battles  I was promised, but it's okay, gotta give some suspension on disbelief. In Fall of the Samurai more people died in a single battle than in the entire war, historically.

The battle system is having the 9 units forming 3 rows and 3 columns, practically making a square. The first 3 lines charge each other and... you watch them fight. In the charging period you need to click once to get a charge bonus. Once a unit is beaten, the one behind them takes its place and starts fighting. There is no flanking if you have taken one of the columns, you just watch units 1v1 each other until one of them drops dead. Archers are worthless because there is a global cooldown on the fire order and at best they can kill 4 dudes from an idle unit before the frontline collapses. And you can never expect an archer unit to excel in melee.

For winning battles you get some resources, then you will wait 10-20 minutes for your injured units to heal. But fear not tovarich, you just need to pay and they are healed instantly.

Oh, and these are game-generated opponents of course. I have not met a way to play against other players besides inviting a friend to a duel, which is a waste of time. Basically: this is a f2p  single player  game which expects you to pay money for its incompetent gameplay. I'm sure they have plans for multiplayer and whatnot, but I honestly feel sorry for programmers who have to work on this pile of unfun ♥♥♥♥.

tl;dr: The design is irredeemable ♥♥♥♥, so do yourself a favour and don't install it. Even better; forget it ever existed

Pros:
-Water physics on the map are cool! You can grow crops and trees faster, if you make it flow next to them!

Cons:
-This game" exists"

reviewText:
I gave it a chance but there isn't anything in the game to grab my interest. The combat is plodding and has no depth, a severe limit to army size and variety, global cooldown when you tell a group of archers to shoot(must be a bug) so you have to wait to even give the order to attack, and limited maneuverablility when in combat which is frustrating.

The city building is decent if simple but trying to build where you want in the geography is needlessly complicated-roads and bridges can only be built on certain elevations. Excavating on land next to a body of water flooded stone I managed to find, building dams and trying to release the water somehow to get the stone didn't work so I gave up.

Buildings and missions are gated behind a honor system which you gain by doing small quests(mostly just building up your city and battles) the early game is very slow and tedious. Building actions like gathering resources or earning money can take hours of time but can be expedited by using purchasable currency, also certain combat buffs can be purchased. Rather than have different outfits for your avatar or skins for units as their money maker his is where the developers chose to setup the gameshop, a clear pay-to-win formula.

As it stands the game does not offer anything of value worth the effort of installing and hours of waiting involved to get anywhere.

reviewText:
After putting some more time into this, I retract my thumbs up. I dont recommend it at all anymore. Even as an Idle game.
The combat is simple and fun, like rock-paper-scissors fun, and the game has a few cool features like terraforming the land...but thats about it.

The reward for actively playing is extra silver or resorces for winning in combat. You spend that to build up your kingdom. The only reason to build up your kindom is to build barracks to build your army. Everything else like farming, mining, and tree harvesting, is just too cumbersome to even bother. What they do in hours, your army can do in moments all on its own. Most idle games continue their task whether you are on or not. This game, when assigned to harvest, it does it, but once its done with the task, it stops until you tell it to go again. Now doing this for every farm, mine, blacksmith, tavern, peasant house, and tree farm, It gets cumbersom and annoying. Their timers dont end at similiar times, and the amount of resorces you get for it is minimal. Not to mention, you are out those resorces if you log in late.

If the pace on resource gathering was a bit faster, and resource buildings were automatic, this wouldnt be a bad game. But since thats combersome, and there is no need for it anyway...there is no point. Taking the fun out of both sides of the game. I would play a game with a map like that if everything about it was more along the lines of the normal Total War franchise. With scaleable armies, resource management, and rewards you for your time.

reviewText:
Runs better than Rome II and Attila combined.  10/10

-----

THIS IS NOT A TRADITIONAL TOTAL WAR GAME.  There.  You’re warned.

Of the handful of free-to-play, castle-style games I’ve tried, they have been a handful too many.  Stronghold Kingdoms was either too lonely or filled with inter-House drama.  Sparta: War of Empires was too deceptive with its trailers and required zero micro.  Kingdom Wars had too many bugs and performed too poorly.  Upon reading several negative reviews, I convinced myself internally that this game would prove no better.

Total War Battles: KINGDOM is none of any of those bad things.

KINGDOM, firstly, plays very, very smoothly and quickly.  Controls are responsive and the game doesn’t waste your time.  “But stuff takes forever to grow and collect!!”  Not my point.  When you are in-game and interacting with the world, you don’t encounter slowdowns, or annoyingly-long cutscenes, or needless exposition.  The engine is a well-oiled machine, undoubtedly.  The music is also really good, complementing the game without getting in the way.

KINGDOM’s depth really sells it, mind you.  The Realm overworld map is hex-based in style, with each space viable for manipulation: elevation, irrigation, terrain type, etc.  Building placement encourages wise structure layout.  During battles, your formation and tactics matter in equal measure. (a qualm I have is that the archers’ ranged attack acts like an ability and does not auto-fire on enemies; I assume this is done to encourage micro, but it’s more tedious than tactical)  Warfare requires very simple, but constant, micro.  It’s not too overwhelming, but also not set and forget."

And judging by the speed at which units gain experience and upgrade
recommended:
so much more to do.

“But Gold makes it pay-to-win!!”

Accept it.  There is no way around that.  The amount of PvE and personal kingdom development

reviewText:
I was able to play this game in the BETA and liked it in the first place.
With the new beta update from February however they completely managed to outbalance the game.
Whilst this game is marketed as something you could play across all devices from time to time you cannot even stop playing really without loosing something. The costs are insanely high and make it impossible for me to enjoy TWBK.

Granted it is still a BETA and I hope for a though rebalancing. If this happens I will be willing to test this game through its paces again, and enjoy it.

Currently it consists of grinding galore, non intuitive and often unexplained constraints. There is lack of tooltips and explaining, despite there is a short tutorial.

TWBK begins easy peasy but it starts to get very hard if you played it a longer time than just 20 hours, as most of the reviewers did.


TWBK, traditionally to Total War games has a great concept and fresh ideas, and it could get somewhere.
If this small CA works hard to aim this game also for casual players, instead of tailoring it to people with no life, or a big wallet for getting ingame currency, it will be fine. Currently it is disencouraging for me.

Sad enough some blame me I play it wrong" because I don't have conquered 3 regions in a couple of hours

reviewText:
As an early starter and being quite active I had an advantage over other non pay to win players so I would win a majority of PvP battles, that was quite fun and the win money helps build up the kingdom, however there's a % of players that pay to win and befriending them you get free gold on their gold purchases. I was amazed at the amount of money they were pouring into the game.

Over a few days the gulf between me an non pay to win against a pay to win was evident and very frustrating as it is almost a guarentee that they win the PvP. I would get the same pay to win person over and over. Other non payers must be loosing interest, also being frustrated.

On the other hand you don't need to play PvP and can do quest/mission battles instead. However at 20 mins wait for a lvl 2 unit to heal if NOT PAYING means I waste too much time looking and waiting for things to click....

So the micro management, A lot of the time you do things and then find out you can't get what you need, ie you build a 2nd knights quaters to recruit more knights only to find you are restricted to only one knight. The reasource collecting is not bad at first but becomes painful as you progress with high costs and too many things you need to improve to increase your reasource pool, with things having different producer times you can spend hours on the game looking and waiting 5 mins between doing something and really when you look back you haven't actually achieved much.

It's a nice looking addictive game and the battles can be fun and frustrating, the tactics are quict simple and rely more on differences in army units and how quick you can click but over all there is little strategy to the game. The strategy is basically what to build where, how to maximim and prioritise reasources.

reviewText:
First, ignore any review that mentions this not being like other Total War games as a negative. It is not meant to be.
It is also not pay to win, because there is no winning, and the wait times for things like growing crops and such are a few hours, perfectly reasonable for this type of game.

Now for my review. To put it briefly, good idea but needs work. The game essentially tries to combine elements of Total War, Civilization, and farmville-style games into one. The problems?
1. the Total War element, the battles, are terrible. Wayy to basic and repetetive, battle maps are too small. Not fun. Also the rewards are so minimal there is little incentive to do them.
2. There is no purpose, drive to the game. No reason to push forward and in that sense the farmville-style element of it is a little too strong.

For the above two reasons, I would not recommend this game. As I play this, I really just get the urge to play Total War or Civilizations, it does not do what it should to mesh these game types together in a way that can stand alone.

reviewText:
I'm extremely conflicted about recommending this game.  So let me say that overall I'd recommend it as a single player game, but the multi-player mode is just as most reviews here say.  Multi-player is pay to win.

There are enough reviews that talk about just how pay to win the multi-player part of the game is and that's the part I would not recommend, so I'm just going to skip talking about that.  Let's just say those people are absolutely correct and there are plenty of reviews that talk about it if you want to read about it.

What I do recommend is playing the game as a single player game.  It's a pretty okay simulation if you avoid playing against people who have paid to build themselves up.

Alone you have this season changing strategy game where the elements can work against you.  Most people will be warned about Flooding early on, semi ignore the warning, and then be wrecked when that first flood comes in.  You can build dams but they can break depending on how much pressure is on them.

Every season brings changes to the game and some things you have to do over a number of seasons.  For instance, you can semi recover from some flooding issues and get land back if you build temporary dams and then make a channel that leads the water to the sea - but there will be some places that the water can still be stuck depending on how you dug things out.  If you try to deal with it during most seasons the water is too deep to do much and you can't build it up.  If you wait until winter when the water freezes, you can chip out the ice and then bend the landscape to however you want it - considering of course that the high waters will return sometime along.

As you play more functions open up that are somewhat interesting.  And while the game may not be super deep at the moment (there's a Campaign that supposedly is coming but it isn't in the game yet) it's pretty decent for a free to play game if you just do the single player stuff.

You can take as much time as you want building up and such before doing things in the single player version, you see exactly who and what you're going against before you take them on, etc.

The novelty of what happens during the season changes will probably wear off over time and all I'm sure.  But for a while if you stick to the single player version of the game it's actually pretty cool and recommended.

Fighting others is completely voluntary, so if you want to try this game out you can do so without fear of being destroyed by overpowered pay to win players.

There are always options in expanding your realm so far so that you can avoid ever having to do the multi-player part of the game if you don't want to.  It definitely can be more costly than just doing some multi-player battles but at least there still is a way to avoid them if you want here (although that's only a good thing because the multi-player game is pay to win, if it was more fair there wouldn't be a lot of reason to avoid it).

I know there will be people that are upset the multi-player portion is pay to win and they won't play the game at all, they will keep far away from it because of that.  That is fine and great if you want to do that.  For me I'd rather just play the single player portion and let the Devs see I'm happy with that part of the game but not the multi-player part.  It's totally up to you what to do with your time but if you want to test it out you can get in with a quick download and test the waters (so to speak - you'll see what I mean :P) in the single player portion without worrying about dealing with the Wallet Warrior Whales that may dominate the multi-player game.

reviewText:
This Game has had mostly negative reviews, but I believe that is due to the miscomprehension of what this game actually is supposed to be. People compare this to other total war titles and, of course, it falls short of expectations. The truth is this really is something different. The only reasons it has the total war stamp is for publicity and because it also has a historical backdrop. However, this is not a bad game.

1st - it is multi-dimensional: There is the aspect of building your land, yes, but there is also the aspect of battles.

2nd - there is change: water rises and lowers; there are floods and droughts, and there are seasons which significantly change the way you play the game, so it stays fresh. Also, there are a lot of combinations of units you can use in battle, and even more unplayable units, for example danes and picts.

3rd - waiting is not crippling: Remember this is a mobile game. Things take time to build, and people have lives. If there was no waiting, a dedicated idiot who played 16h a day would win the game easily. Instead, everyone has a chance if they can actually fight, which brings us to battles. if your units don't lose too many people, you don't have to wait. Waiting is a punishment for losing battles, or a necessary thing for building and collecting resources. Also, people keep saying this game has 8h waiting periods, but most times the waiting is 20 mins or so. It is like that with units and most collecting resources. If you decide to fell a whole forest, yeah, it is gonna take 8h, but that is dumb to begin with. Forests don't just grow back, certainly not when you wipe the whole thing out at the same time.

4th - though gold can help you win, you cannot pay to win after the first few weeks. Once people actually have time to craft some special units, it becomes impossible to pay to win. The only ways you can help yourself with gold is by not waiting (which helps very little) and by getting special units (which you can also craft, though that takes longer), and special bonuses (which, again, you can craft). It is a known fact that, if you spend too much money on a game, you get bored easily and stop playing - too much money, too little reward. So after the first few weeks, older players who stick with it will be mopping the floor with younger players with lots of money.

5th - Again, this is not a proper total war title. This is for waiting rooms, for work breaks, for commuting, etc. If you want a past time for that, this is a good choice. If you want a game to play at home, do yourself a favor and buy rome and/or attila. That's what steam sales are for.

6th - comparison with other mobile games: this game is so much better than any other mobile games i've seen, it is not even fair. Candy crush, farmville, and the like are basically the same thing over and over again. There is very little difference. Also, here at least you get a (very tiny albeit existant) bit of history. You at least learn that there were picts and danes in england. To be honest, there should be more information about that, as well as about the game mechanics. But this is a beta, so I expect that will eventually show up - I HOPE. And you can just enjoy a casual game. If you want something else, something more encompassing, get another game.

Still, not bad. For what it is.

reviewText:
I've been on Steam several years and this is the first time I've felt like I need to write a review.

What is the point of this game?  It reminds me of Paradise Life with castles.  Quite simply no reason to continue playing.  Last month of gameplay for me was logging in for 2 minutes to gather resources and restart constructions, then exit and go play something fun.

City building, terrain altering, and water mechanics were fun.

Crafting system is terrible and very grindy, in addition to relying on RNG.  This is your alternative to the gold shop if you want the better available combat units and equipment; and not much of one at that.

Battles are pay to win.  You will see people say that it is not pay to win because you can get all the same things if you grind enough.  That is technically true; but it takes so long to grind for those things that you are at a severe disadvantage for a really long time.  You can pay to win now, or grind to win a long time from now.

In addition, I had first installed this game on my PC and played for a while.  Once it was released, I installed it on my phone and logged into my (same) account.  My Kingdom on PC and on my Phone were completely separate despite being on the same account.  Not cross-compatible.

I do not recommend this game.  Do not waste your time like I did.  Go play something else.

reviewText:
if it looks like a mobile game, feels like a mobile game and has the micro transaction system of a mobile game, chances are it is a mobile game.
This however did not stop me from trying and I found it to be quite enjoyable to be honest.
Although it does carry the name Total war the battle system is rather simplistic compared to the actual series.
But to its more simple nature I found it easy to play in between other activities.

The micro transaction system is worth a special mention, as unlike my expectations you are not forced to use it.
As major part of this game is technically single player you have plenty of options available without using gold.

Overall a decent game to fill smaller time gaps between activities.

reviewText:
First there are invisible(pay) walls everywhere. You need 2 towns to upgrade your first( there is a limit on number of buildings in town). Healing weak units take 10-15min, but for better units this may be a lot more. Best units are only for real money. For a day you can make around 1k coins grinding the battles. Mine or farm need 700 for level 2.

Town setup is just for show. Noone is going to atack you, so there is no point in walls or some trategy in using the rivers.

Battles are fun at start, but become repetitive super fast, still you will need to grind more and more to upgrade the units you have.  Also AI ( if you can call it that) make stupid mistakes, like sending archers on front line.

On mobile (and all wait times lowered by 70-80%) this will be great game, but here is like a good looking shameless money grab.

reviewText:
If I have the right to give points to this game, I'd give it 5,5/10. I know it is the first day of release and it is possible that a lot of content are going to come in the future, but this phase of development are still filled things that deeply dissatisfies me. Some of the reasons are listed below:

1. Too much freemium.

1.a 50% of the units you can train ingame can only be bought (at this moment) by gold, which is the real world currency translation ingame. Albeit these units are beatable, it would took a lot of effort to beat one, especially the cavalry units.

1.b To upgrade your units with armors and weapons, you need gold. Sure the first upgrades are purchasable: +2 damage or +2 defense for 18 golds. But +4 damage for 3 times the price? And +6 damage for 8 times the price of the 1st item? Personally I'm not going to think its worth my while.

1.c Costumization ain't costumzation at all. First, the original costumization is very, very limited. And guess what could you do to get another color or pattern scheme? 45 golds at minimal. If I'm to unlock all costumization possible, I'd probably able to spare for a meal in a restaurant.

1.d Speeding up times; unless you are very patient on your woodcutter and farm, you might want to check this game once every 20 minutes, since it is usually the interval between starting things and things get done. 20 Stones for 1 hour is long enough, 20 silver for 4 hours and you have to collect workers and send them to work in the smith? The quicker way to get money is really just being a problem solver: fighting picts, rebels, and vikings.

1.e Your army is too weak to beat up vikings? Don't worry, just with 2 or 3 golds per battle, you can gain support from mercenaries, or buy flaming arrow for the duration of the battle, or hire an old man as your short-time military advisor.

2. Landscaping system: your enemy and your friend. With thelandscaping system in place, players are faced with new challenges in city building: floods and height control. Some buildings require landscaping which albeit payable with ingame resources, are quite fussy. There are some restrictions on landscaping which might forces you to destroy and rebuilt buildings quite often. I just visited the forum and found a thread about flooding. If this is true, then you would want to keep watch on the game for flooding, since flooding literally disrupts your army and silver income.

3. Complicated building system. As said, you don't only need reaources to build buildings, you need other things you want to consider before building things: leaving enough space for other buildings to connect indirectly to your castle being one example. The other one is how much space would your farms take to maximize your food output or the reach of your woodcutter to maximize your wood output. Or how many houses or slums or mansions you have to build if you want to keep your blacksmiths running smoothly.

4. Quests that are too demanding" SPOILER ALERT: DO NOT HUNT ANY DEERS

reviewText:
PLAY NOW FOR FREE... BULL$HIT!

Pay to play/win/progress waste of time.

Build a farm, no problem, wait 4 hours for the fields to come in or spend 1 gold (for each field) to speed it along.  Running low on food and you need to harvest everything at once? Wait 8 hours or spend 5 gold to speed it along!

The resource cost to build something is so inflated in comparison to how much you can collect per node of resource it will take you hours if not days to collect enough to build anything. This forces you to spend/purchase gold to move the game along.

Only play this if you have a lot of time to waste or money to burn.

reviewText:
Posted: 3 May 2015
I have always loved Total War games and recommends them all including Total War Battles: Shogun.
But this is the worst kind of games, a free Pay to win game that is not even worth the download.
I have never before had such a bad experience with a Total War game.

Update: 20 Sep 2015
The game have improved, BUT there's still too much Pay to win and gameplay issues.
Such as paying for the best units from the very beginning!
Issues like clicking on enemy units instead of your own to use abilities. Why would I want to click on enemy units to begin with?
They seriously also need to add more tooltips to EVERYTHING! Where are the explanations to anything? Do I really have to spend resources and time, only to find out that what I did was useless or less effective?

reviewText:
Played this 30 minutes, just long enough to do 4 battles and confirm my thoughts on the game.Normally I would spend more time before reviewing a game, but unless this game is secretly frog fractions later on(spoiler: its not) then I have no more content I need to know how I feel about this game.

It is like a clash of clansy game where it has a building your city bit and a battles bit. I did not even get far enough to see if it is pay to win, looking at it, doesn't look pay to win but heck even if it was- its like saying Daikatana is pay to win. Oh nooooooo!!

Cities:
Honestly I don't care how good this is. Maybe it is good I don't know.What this game has to hold it up would be good battles.

Battles:
Really game? '3 lanes' with nearly turn based combat that is clearly made to be played on a tablet/phone? You put your little dudes in the right lane setups and then use rock paper scissors style combat with minimal input(click on your dudes at the right time to charge! Use a taunt on those archers!).

Maybe if you like timegated games with turn based combat this could be fun. As someone who likes total war games this is not for me.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VwCD53wlDgs < go play some actual total war

Sure this could be a decent game for your phone. I don't know that. As it is on my pc as a 1.6GB download, I get to compare it to things like:
-League of legends
-Cities Skylines/any other total war game
-World of Tanks
-Age of Empires Online
-Any facebook game
-Cookie Clicker

As such this game focuses on being lite strategy and a little building expansion game. If i want lite strategy there are a bunch of strategy lite F2P games on steam that do not feel the need to cripple the player behind timewalls.

This is the steam store page not the apple store page.

reviewText:
TL;DR: Some game breaking bugs and too much P2W advantage kills any good things this game has.

Not as bad as some reviews said if you are used to play those web games to fill up fragmented time. But ther is too much P2W feeling since the game is designed to force you to either spend some money or wait for days for somewhat higher end stuff. I can see CA put in some good efforts in the game, like having seasonal changes and stuff. However, the gameplay just falls short of expectation due to the p2w factors being too stronk.

For a F2P game like this, it is much better not to be so blunt about microtransactions while providing some gameplay with more depth and fun factors. I would rather spend 100 bucks on Kancolle than this thing.

Also, BUGS! I constantly getting d/c when trying to do a battle quest. and when I logged back, it just locks my army saying that it is in a duel for hours. WTF?!!!1

reviewText: Before I start I just want to say that I grew up on Total War games starting at Shogun. Being a diehard strategy fan, the series rubbed me in all the right spots. Unfortunately this one is a blemish on CA and the series. I understand that it may get better and that it’s still in development but oi vay. Anyway on to my review, the good points are that this game has a fun geo terrain aspect to it in which you can alter terrain to move water and rivers around. This can be fun and challenging at times as during flooding season your whole city can be flooded if you don’t know what you’re doing. I also enjoyed the tile aspect of buildings in which you can get different bonuses depending on how you pair up buildings and where you place them. The battles are scaled down obviously as this is aimed for tablet and phone platform. This kills strategy completely as battles come down to how upgraded your troops are and what gear you have purchased or smithed for them. Early on the only way to get good gear is to spend real cash on it, this gear will open up and be possible to craft later on in the game but you have to make it far to be able to do that. This makes the early phases very pay 2 win as you will struggle against even AI w/o gear. And dont get me started on other players, I didnt even mess with PvP after a few tries as the 5 people I tried fighting completly demolished me because all their troops were high end and fully maxed on gear where as I did not spend money and decided to get ther gear the hard way. The other aspect of battles is the charge mechanic in which you dictate when your squad charges the enemy. Your troops slowly start moving toward one another and if you time it right and click on the squad at the right time to charge you can get a damage bonus. This is very basic and has no strategy to it, to me the total war series was all about the battle mechanics. Now I know you can’t make a massive battle game work for touch screen but I feel they could have put more effort into it and included other detail. I do still want to see how it plays on my touch device though. The other downside is the ridiculous wait times to gather resources such as 8 hours for some (which has been mentioned before). I feel as though this game is aimed to take your money and nothing more, hopefully they improve it as it stand now this game was made to take your green paper with little to none fun compensation. For now, I am giving this one a thumbs down.

reviewText:
I have been a big fan of the TW series for many years now and I can say for sure that this game has very little to do with the other games.
It’s a very standard “browser” type game, that you can’t play in a browser, it’s similar to the Stronghold online game but a bit worse.
Possitive: interesting fighting mechanics
Neggative: you can’t enjoy this game if you don’t invest a lot of money, examples:
-either you pay 4 gold or wait 8 hours for 10 food from a crop (now consider you need 150 food a barrack)
-people who will pay get acces to much better units, sure you can get a free unit but you will loose your duels no matter the strategy
-everything in this game screams give us money
I don’t think that CA understood how the the free games market works, and I am sorry for that. I would be willing to make purchases in game, but everything should be the same in terms of chances for everyone.

1/10

reviewText:
First of all : this is not a Total War game ! This is a medieval city-builder with some battles elements, designed for phones. If you're looking for a total war skip this and go play total war arena instead.
Does it make it a bad game ? No. Well. Depends what you're looking for.

Pros
- Nice atmosphere. Immersive and relaxing.
- Fun city and terrain management. Nothing complicated.
- Batte system is great once you understand how it works.
- Not P2W, but....

Cons
- Takes forever to get gold by playing. If you are duelling other players you'll be at a disadvantage until you get a good economy.
- If you want things done fast... don't play.
- If you want a deep total war battle system or campaign, don't
- if you want deep city management, don't

To sum it up : if you want a relaxing little game where you build cities and battle, then it's good.

reviewText:
So Total War Battles: KINGDOM is finaly here but what does this really mean. In the last year or so we have seen so many of these games, mine resources and anothers base. However never have we seen something like this on this scale, on PC. This mix of continuous world strategy and good old real time strategy battles seems to work quite well, however some of those battles can get a little confusing.

Issues such as markability and platform prefrencing are big issuse CA is going to have to think about. One of my biggest issues with this game is the realism scenario, does CA really expect me to sit at my computer for 30-60 mins playing a game like this, its not the sort of game you do that with. I dont know about you but I dont really feel like sitting at my PC waiting 30 mins for something to be collected.

Now dont get me wrong there are a lot of good features about this game and I thought battles would be one of them, I wouldnt say I was wrong they do have some fun parts to them, like seeing those little guys dance for victory or the dead corpses for lose. But one of the battles most basic mechanics have been totaly screwed up, 'charges' more like a nice walk in the park unless the person controling you is sliding his mouse across his desk back and forth like a maniac. Look I seriously think that this could work on an iPad or Tablet but seriously a PC?

I think there are large chunks of this game that are really purpose built for iPad's and or Tablets. Overall I wouldnt say its a bad game, because its not but there is still a lot of improvements to be done before I will consider calling it a polished game. I know lots of you die hard fans will disagree with me but that the point of a review, me giving my opinion. And there it is!

TheMooseConqueror (Aiden)

reviewText: It's free and nice to do during study. Ofcourse it is pay to win as in you can pay to get a headstart or you need to throw hundreds of bucks at this game and then you are really paying to win. The majority won't do that so its fine. You can create your own city and change the landscape which is really cool. You can battle other players with a matchmaking system that is pretty fast. Do single player, chain battles or a campaign. It keeps me entertained which is pretty much what I want from a game. However that you can battle every 5 min indefinetely tends to favour the active person vs the login once, twice a day people which i think is a mistake. The health of the unit card should drop x from a lost fight and less from winning and this enables you fight 5 to 15 fights depending on if you win or lose and by how much.

Fourth, you have to build first to see where is best option to put certain buildings, there are no clues where is best suitable for them.

reviewText:
A good concept, but hampered by its Free-to-Play model.

The Good:
I love the art style, and the music is passable. The hexagon-based simple city building has promise. I like the variation of the seasons, and that they actually have gameplay effects. I like how terrain, especially access to water, affects resource gathering. I like how terrain will change—grass will spread, trees will regrow. Combat is simple, but fun. A good mix of units, and there is room for effective tactics (and not just spamming orders buttons) to change the outcome of a battle.

The Bad:
I do not like the running-clock mechanism; it makes the game feel like FarmVille or other FtP “FaceBook games.” Construction takes no appreciable time at all, but gathering resources hours or even days without forking over cash for in-game currency. Some of these times work (e.g. about 20 minutes to fully refresh an army after a defeat or pyric victory), others don’t (hours of quarrying for a measly 20 stone). So, really, what I don’t like is that it is free-to-play.

The Ugly:
I think if they had kept the core of the game (the map, the combat model, terrain modification, hex-based town construction, seasonal variation), but instead reworked it as a stand-a-lone game WITHOUT the FtP model and constantly running clock, this could have been a solid “midrange” or “light” game. If seasons were “turns,” and certain things (planting, harvesting, etc.) could only be done during particular seasons, the game would be much more enjoyable to just sit an play—instead play for about an hour or less then log out and come back in 12 hours or so. Such a game would necessitate a complete reworking of the way resources were handled, but a price-point of $30-40 would have made such a game a must-buy for me. As it is, I’ll fiddle until I get bored of the grind, then shelve it—and they likely won’t have made any money off of me.

reviewText:
I stupidly decided to play for 3 hours yesterday.  Went to bed, woke up, and realized how stupid I was.

All I can really focus on are the negatives...

1. Pay to win
- The better units require gold (which is purchased, with a very small amount coming from random events and such).  For example, a barracks allows you to recruit swordsmen, spearmen, macemen, and axemen.  The macement and axemen require gold.
- the game is about gathering resources based on timers, but the timers can be instantly finished by spending gold.  Want tons of resources?  You can pay to get them!

2. Complete utter timesink
- Assuming you're masochistic enough to decide to play, all the timers are ♥♥♥♥ed up:
Some are 4hours, some are 6, some are 8.  So if you want to maximize your income, you better log in all the time
- There are battle missions which you can constantly do for more resources.
But heavily damaged units require time to heal (or, of course, spend more gold!  PAY TO WIN!).  These timers take around 5-30 minutes.  So again, the more you play, the more resources you get...  better check into the game all the time, or else you won't get those resources!

reviewText: Honest review from a PC and Moblie gamer. I often have to work late and have long periods of time where I have to kill free time. Since acquring the Iphone 6 Plus, I've started playing games like Clash of Clans, COD heros and other forms of mobile games. Games that you can have quick action, such as couple of battles... then attend to resources and or upgrade buildings if need too. Saying that takes 10 minutes, then you are done, recieved a fix and move one. That's what a standard mobile game has become, that's what people do with mobile games. Play with it until something else comes up, and you come back to it in 15 minutes or 10 hours. Which total war kingdom follows that same pattern. The PC master race me, wants the climb to the tallest building AND SCREAM LIKE F*CKING INSANE PERSON at everybody! This is simply not a pc game, NOBODY WANTS TO WAIT for construction for 8 hours, PC games aren't a pick up and stop games like mobile games. This game has no right to be called a pc game and should have never launched for the pc. When I play total war on the pc, I want hard throbbing, none stop action like a chick in a gangbang. This pc version, fall quite short of that. Then again, I am looking forward to it on my Iphone 6 plus though.

reviewText: The Total War series is epic and then......poo.  I think that Sega ate something bad in order to produce this pile.  From the washed out colors to the lane based fighting,  the game really just rains all over the Total War series.  Instea of sweet flanking moves your stuck with lane based fighting.  Instead of huge expansive fighting maps, your stuck with tiny maps that just barely fill a 1080p screen.  Oh the graphics btw, their washed out.  Really really washed out. I mean they took the most awful pastels they could find and used those for this game.  Also, where the hell are the options?  OH, I see, the game was designed for mobile apps and then uploaded on steam. Hmm, where does it say that it's a mobile app, oh thats right it doesn't.  Also, wtf is up with these time based buildings. Want some wheat? Want some ore? Yup mine it, and uh oh, it's going to take 18 minutes for that to happen.  Ofcourse you can spend gold to speed that process up.  Hmm sounds like some other cash grab games.  Oh those resources you just sped up, you gotta manually pick them up.  What a complete pile of poo. Sega should have given us a good version of Total War.  Hell I love the series and would have paid premium  prices for it. Instead we are left with........bleh....

reviewText:
I'd like to begin this review by saying that I am a great fan of Total War, and I have played almost all the games in the series - from the first Rome to the newest 'Attila'. While Creative Assembly does trip, sometimes, in the development of their games, they always manage to fix the bugs and provide additional - and fun - content to their players, in the end, and create high quality products for both strategy fans and newbies who try out the genre for the first time.

'nuff said, I had high expectations for Total War Battles: KINGDOM. As always, Creative Assembly managed to meet them all, and hit the nail.


Total War Battles: KINGDOM is a perfect example of what Creative Assembly can make with dedication, effort and love. A blend of city building and those large scale battles we all loved, with deep gameplay and even a lil' bit of customization for our character. Players will pass hours trapped with the game on their pc (and even outside, thanks to the innovative tablet/phone support), as they create the reign of their dreams, command several troops in bloody battles, and duel against other players' armies. Total War Battles: KINGDOM is truly a high quality game of this generation.


But allow me to describe this game in depth, if you still are not convinced about trying it out.


STORY

Sadly, I cannot write much about this yet. This current Beta doesn't have a campaign, but I fully expect it to be released in the future, peraphs trough a cheap DLC or a transaction with the in-game 'gold'.

GRAPHICS

Well. The graphics on Total War Battles: KINGDOM are simply.. beautiful. The details of the landscape and buildings is truly astonishing, and the deep realism of your units' equipment, and features, will make the player be completely immersed within the game. Players will stop to stare at their screen for hours, both in the city  and battle screens, as they observe and fall in love with every graphic detail this game offers.

SOUND

Total War Battles: KINGDOM's sound is well crafted, like the rest of the game, with original and innovative sounds (with some inspiration taken from ROME II) that will accompany the player during their quests and adventures. (I have to admit, however, that I overheard some of my christian soldiers talking about 'gods' during their taunts against the enemy. Peraphs the developers are planning to add a 'religion' expansion, in the future?)

GAMEPLAY

The gameplay is quite different from the previous games in the Total War series. While battles are pretty much the same as the other Total War games, with numerous units battling for you against their enemies, the ability to conquer whole nations was removed. Players now control smaller kingdoms, but are able to efficently customize and control pretty much every aspect to it, like a true city-building game.

It's also worthy to mention about the realism this new game has. 'Turns' got replaced with 'hours', real life hours, that further adds to the realism of Total War Battles: KINGDOM. Everything that will be built or gathered has a timer, and the players will have to wait before the operation is complete - or speed up everything trough the aid of innocent 'Gold'.


Resources in the game are divided in 'Wood', 'Stone', 'Silver', 'Food', and 'Gold'. I don't believe that the first four require too much explanation. They can be gathered from the regions under your reign, and are required to build several buildings.

'Gold', however, is quite different. This resource is only available trough cheap transactions with real-money (completely unneded, of course) and is used to speed-up constructions, resource gathering, troop healing and other processes or to buy, and obtain, new and fresh customization options for your player character, banner and temporary bonuses during battles. In my personal opinion, 'Gold' does not affect the game too much, effectively making this a non-pay-to-win game, and is only really needed if a player wants to buy innocent customizations for themselves.

Players will utilize these resources to create their kingdom, spending them to build new buildings and create entire towns within their regions. They will be also capable of morphing the terrain based on their desires, raising or lowering the terrain and using 'dams' to block the path of rivers, preventing flooding or creating new areas where to build.

Battles are pretty much the same everyone can find in the precendent games. Large armies will fight for their liege in bloody fights, and players will be able to put their personal tactics, and strategic thinking, to work. Bonuses and reinforcements are also available, with 'Gold',  that will help the player in more difficult battles.


FINAL CONSIDERATIONS

In the end, Total War Battles: KINGDOM is a great and enjoyable game, with little flaws and bug despite it's beta state. I recommend every Total War fan to try out this game, since it's completely free, and my words cannot really describe how this game is. I hope that Creative Assembly, and peraphs many other game companies, will continue to provide games like this, and bring game industry to a new golden age.

reviewText:
What might have been an interesting terrain-manipulation puzzle game is being dragged down by being tied to a mediocre PVP dueller.

The compromises they've made in order to turn this into a mobile-style click-the-resource-fest means that while this might look like a decent offering on the App Store, it's very out of place on Steam where there are much better games to be had. Even at this price.

The fact that this is being marketed as a 'Total War' game makes me a little bit queasy. This game is going to do real damage to a valuable brand. There are definitely some marketing pony-tails in the decision making chain that need to be downsized, and quick. IMHO, of course. It's their brand to ruin as they see fit.

reviewText:
Ok now first. This is NOT your typical TW game. It's a time managment game. I repeat TIME MANAGMENT.

reviewText:
I have to sadly say that as many others have pointed out this is a pay to win Facebook game with a total war facelift. The resources required to expand the map are far too high, by the time any player who doesn’t drop money gets access to the higher quality units not to mention higher tier quality a player who drops money is so far ahead there is no way to keep up and be competitive on the PvP section of this game.

The art is great, the combat system is fun and challenging [which is good] the map can be changed to a slight degree lowering and raising the land which is nifty.

However the drawback of in some cases not being able to tell how many enemies you may be facing because they are off the battle field waiting to enter, the obviously pay to win model, and the lack of content long term, I would have to say pass on this game even if it’s free.

Any total war fan will be left wanting more content and more quality, any Facebook fan will be put off by the combat and both parties will not like the pay to win model.

Creative assembly get out of the facebook game and back into making AAA full release games.

reviewText:
Combat is boring, involves QTEs, and makes completely no sense (You'd think that if you kill everyone in a certain lane, you could now flank the enemy with your freed-up troops, but no, you have to wait or taunt, hoping that somebody is stupid enough to saunter into that specific column to fight your idling soldiers.)

Why does it take seven centuries or paying in-game currency to harvest/mine anything in this game. During the tutorial, I found out that harvesting wheat would take either 20 min or 1 gold. So I decided to wait a bit and save up what I could in terms of currency. I come back 10 minutes later and find out that the game has crapped out on itself and needs me to sign back in so it can re-update. Not that bad in and of itself, but it completely canceled my harvesting process, sending the process back to square one, all twenty minutes of it. Let me repeat, this game traps you into paying Gold on what should just be a mouseclick and a bit of a waiting game, because the game cannot support itself long enough to farm the normal, non-idiotic way.

I also learned that if you press a mouse right, your useless looking pitchfork wielders can utterly obliterate the front rank of trained cavalrymen mid-charge. Apparently SEGA didn't remember that this doesn't work ANYWHERE ELSE in the Total War series. Seriously, let's line some peasants up against cavalry and rush them head on in Rome I, Rome II, Shogun II, anything. See if that works.

10/10, would uninstall again.

reviewText:
I can't overstate what a dissapointment this game is.

I was expecting quality that the Total War series has become known for, instead I am handed a game that is some strange mix between Game of War and Clash of Clans, except, amazingly, this game has none of the fun or polish of either.

The battle sequences are convoluted and the AI balanced as such that you are essentially forced to buy units with RL money to progress. The cash shop drives EVERYTHING, without it, resource generating takes an incredibly long time (seriously, DAYS), and the pay to win units are so vastly better than the free ones that it's like playing an entirely different game.

There is no semblence of economic balance either -- it takes a seemingly dispraportionate amount of time to upgrade or build anything to an appreciable size. For instance, once harvested, it takes TWO DAYS OF REAL TIME for a forest to regrow for you to click it and SPENT ANOTHER EIGHT HOURS to harvest it to repeat for...10 wood! Keep in mind, to even get level 2 structures it can cost HUNDREDS of wood. REALLY?

This game is an abortion. Avoid it at all costs.

reviewText:
Great game. A bit slow at times but very addictive (Currently my most played game). Can't wait for the campaign to drop.

Would be nice if more colors were added to the heraldry system. We should also be allowed to have more than one sigil.

One thing that bothers me is the trading console. You have to click once for every little bit of resource you wish to trade. There was a quest to trade 2,000 units in one transaction. Due to my 50% trade rate (the highest I can get) I had to click the LMB 1,000 times to trade 2,000 units. The hard part wasn't gathering the resources but the clicking. Hopefully they can change it to a slider or simply a box for us to type the amount we wish to trade.

All in all it's a game that keeps me coming back to it constantly and I would love it if there was more content added.

reviewText: OK, this game is not the typical Total War game, and yes, its absolutely design with mobile devices in mind. But if you compare it with other games in the genre it is one of the best.
