reviewText:
Great game, this.  It's in the same genre as games like Travian, Clash of Clans, and Tribal Wars with the major difference being that the kingdom building aspect is 100% safe from attack and being conquered by others.

Combat reminds me of the boardgame Oishi if any are familiar.  it is an eastern tactical combat style boardgarme.  games are quick and easy though sometimes a huge fight will boil down to a few hearty troops which is always dramatic.  the combat feels 'jousty' where you have a little clash and then are on your way.

Graphics are great.  The feel of the most recent rome total war is brought forward and refined in this newest total war game.  in the most recent rome total war the iconography felt like cheap clipart, but in total war battles, the iconography has been given the love it needs to become a beautiful part of the rest of the game which is already beautiful.

One of the things that I like most about this game is that I feel like it's the BEST of it's genre because your kingdom will NEVER be destroyed or taken over by another player.  It is your kingdom.  you get 1 life, in that when you start the game you get your character name which is undeletable and tied to your total war account, so if you like your name, no restarts!  I digress though, since what you have is safe and yours, then you can develop your kingdom at your own pace.   I believe the missions scale to how much xp you've got in your army roster but I could be wrong.

Early missions are easy cakewalks and the easy ones can be done without the aid of the relics kept in churches so if you want to do a low religion level game (like for a long time in the beginning of the game, I destroyed almost everything and rebuilt, so my kingdom only had the holy grail providing a special 'order' power for my army for a good long time and I got by just fine).

A last note about the spirit of this game, which I feel is important to talk about.  in other games in this genre, you're left feeling stressed like you could get attacked and lose your stuff at any moment, and the timers were like chains, binding you whether you liked it or not to the game.  In Total War Battles: Kingdom, since your kingdom is safe, the feel is totally different.  You can pick it up whenever you want, put it down whenever you want, take a break for a week who cares?  you can still come back to it and field your army and have fun battles at just your level and enjoy a stress free super beautiful castle builder on the side.

Enjoy!

It's free :)

reviewText:
In short:

I like the game, it has lots of potential .. but it's an ill conceived cash cow that will milk you dry.

Things that ruin this game:

* Increadibly long periods of time to do even the most menial tasks. This is a game where you click and then walk away for a day, a week .. half a month (Yes, chop down and tree and it will take half a month real time to grow back).
* No auto activity feature .. forcing you to micro manage even the most basic resource collection (see previous point).
* Huge reliance on gold to speed things up (purchased with real coin) to make this game even playable (see previous point).
* Increadible difficulting in raising gold through the actual game (see previous point).

So unless you fork out huge amounts of real cash, be prepared to wait until retirement before anything exciting happens.

reviewText:
This game really isn't for fans of previous Total War games but it's charming in it's own right. Even when you loose battles you'll progress which makes the game less discouraging and the quick play times means this game directly appeals to the mobile market. Unlike most MMO's out there TWB Kingdoms won't suck the soul out of your life once you start playing it.

On the downside though, you'll find it difficult to obtain special weapons and troops without spending money or doing some serious soul sucking grinding. Overall it's OK, I enjoyed my around 12+ hours I spent playing it.

reviewText:
THIS FREE TO PLAY GAME CAN BE AN EXPENSIVE RIP OFF!!!

The two most serious problems I ran into are like boom - a gambling addiction I didn't know I had, and bugs like this one below that COST A PLAY REAL MONEY - boo-hiss.

I had to send this into Tech Support, hope I don't have to pay $$$ to get a quick resolution and action like in the game.

USE RENOWN TO ACCESS WEDGEFORD NOT WORKING!

As I understand the criteria, to rule Wedgeford a player can either buy the territory which is IMPOSSIBLE unless one pays TOO MUCH real money for it OR proves right to rule by becoming a renowned duelist.

Lady Evelyn defines renowned duelist as “OBTAIN DUELING RANK 18 OR BETTER.”

After achieving a dueling rank of 20 for several days, I am still now able to USE RENOWN to obtain Wedgeford.

Hopefully, this is a game bug that needs attention, or this game is really the PAY TO PLAY RIP OFF noted by far too many reviewers.

I’m at the point where I must compare this game to getting addicted to on line gambling – slot machines.

Is the game different from most other Total War games? Most definitely.

However, the biggest difference is the FREE TO PLAY label is most misleading, thus far I’ve spent $55.00 bucks to play this so called free game. I have about $9.00 left in my game account, so when I (admittedly) foolishly get that ripped off, I’m uninstalling this game from STEAM.

In fact the negative review I found to be my favorite is: About as pay to win' as you can get. Shame on CA for stooping to a level I associate with doing the video gamer equivalent of running a casino direct targeting gambling addicts. A certain type of player will blow god awful amounts of money on this. The more rational gamers will be annoyed that those who spent a ton of money have such an advantage.

There are definitely a few positives to this game
date: but the negatives far outweigh the misleading FREE TO PLAY BETA.\n\nSincce this is a Beta
recommended: and SEGA desires feedback from those (PAYING TO) play this FREE GAME
hoursPlayed: I strongly suggest that instead of getting more folks addicted to gambling (like me)
voteText: that SEGA put this much time
helpfulPercent: effort

and talent into turning this into a real traditional Total War platform and simply charge an up front price for the game.

Here are a few other comments I found most useful.

- The tutorial itself teaches you how to spend money – REAL MONEY from your Steam Account.
- It's a "pay to win" game as you can get everything by simply paying.
- All customization and speedups

reviewText:
A totally different take on the Total War franchise. This is a much limited game suitable to be played on a mobile device. Do not expect to play a full Total War classic game, those games need beefier computers.

So taking this game for what it is, a mobile game, it is surprisingly good, beatiful graphics and quite some Kingdom management options plus the combat aspect where the composition of your army, its positioning, upgrades and orders are all important. It is meant to be played esporadically, for 10 minutes at a time, loging a few times a day to manage your Kingdom.

It is also a free game with no ads and a non intrusive gold for money shop. Money gives you gold which allows you to speed up everything (buying units instead of slowly gathering resources to slowly craft them; instant construction of buildings, instant gathering of resources or instant healing your troops after the battle instead of waiting the rrequired time). So the impatient will spend money to buy gold to progress faster... and that is good, because the rest of us get to play for free at our own pace.

Every unit or improvement that can be bought with gold can be crafted in game, provided you manage your kingdom properly and take your time. Heck, I have got more gold in game than I need too.

So enjoy the game for what it is, a beautiful, well done, FREE mobile game.

---------------------------------------

Note: Some personal advice, the game does not detail every aspect of how everything works. the way I see it, I find it more fun to play the game WITHOUT looking in internet for detailed notes about how the buildings work or how the seasons affect your economy. Play the game and discover it yourself without any external hints. It is supposed to be a challenge where setbacks leads to learning.

Note that you CANNOT restart the game, but nothing you'll do would break it. You can always recover from everything that the game throws at you, so if a season drought or an invasion wreak havoc with your budding Kingdom, take it as a challenge and raise again without ♥♥♥♥♥ing at how unfair the game is.

reviewText: Well it’s been a while since this came out and now I will write what I have to say on it. Like its real time predecessor total war battles shogun the game is different in nature to other total war titles. However for this version the gameplay was split. In battles shogun you had to build buildings and train troops during the battles which behaved in a similar format. Your troops would mindlessly march across the hex based map and the only thing you could do to them was switch lanes. At this point not counting the pay to accelerate system in place there are a lot of gameplay problems with the game. unlike total war battles shogun the management and battles are split up. In this version  you have a hex based grid where you build villages that take forever to gather resources and also require player interaction to do so. The battles are summed up with your troops mindlessly go towards the enemy with a few player interactions in charging and ability’s to break up the boring aspect of battles. Now the part that really pisses me off and arguably breaks the game is the difficulty system. The game scales difficulty based on how powerful your army is and the game was designed with the logic “hey let’s make the AI more powerful than you all the time to make the game challenging.” The problem with that logic is that you get to a point where the AI is so powerful it takes any fun that’s left out of the game. Worse is that when the AI is weaker than you there is no reward for winning. The ridiculous difficulty is seen with the raiders that attack your villages every so often. Now for some reason raiders are not scaled with your army for difficulty. Instead they are scaled with the number of regions under your control. So I have 4 regions and am facing armies that have troops that are so powerful that I can only get through one line of troops with all 3 lines of my troops filled.(there are 3 lines in total for both sides and apparently the AI can get reinforcements) Raiders steal your resources and destroy your buildings so you have to get rid of them. If you can’t defeat them in battle you have to pay them silver (one of the resources in the game) the problem there is that the raiders demand ludicrous amounts of silver in the last case they demanded over 4000 silver which drained days (and I mean real world days) worth of resource gathering. That’s not mentioning the yearly droughts that dry up the rivers over halfway up the map, and the pay to accelerate system that is in place. It’s worth noting that this is a beta and I do hope that many of these problems get fixed but until they do I cannot recommend this game to anyone.

reviewText: Ok I have played the game for some time now and have 3 regions and only one level 2 castle which took forever to grind  to get there. I tried to get the 4th region but the units they have are all level 2 and  3 units and they also have a onager that just flat out wipes your level 1 units off the map. So I figured yea this looks to be pay to win so what do I do I drop $20.00 to get some better units . Oh guess what you can only buy 1 of those units lol.... but your enemy has 3 of that unit and they are level 2 and 3 you lose. So next I figure I will just try level the one unit but guess what you need to level that building first!! OMG!!!.... yes for every unit you have you have to level that building up first to make it rank 2 unit and it costs 1800 of one resource and 1500 of some other resource to complete just one building.  Not sure what it will cost to go rank 3 but I can imagine a heck of alot more for sure!!....And you still have to grind to level up those units too. My concern is I noticed in the video it says that you protect your lands from other players. Though I have not been invaded by any players only AI so far.  But my concern is after all the time you spend on trying to level everything and spend real money just to lose everything to someone else who is Rich and wants your Land . your just SOL.. Not sure if thats just multiplyer version or not.  Single player version is all that is available atm.  But you can battle other players in what they call a Duel..  So my 2 cents is if you have alot of time and money this game is for you if not stay away.  I'm going to continue playing it since I have already donated to it and see what happens down the road when the campaign part opens up. I will then post another  review then.

reviewText:
This game seems pretty fun. Altough it should not carry the Total War title + logo since there is almost no aspect from a Total War game in. Kingdom Wars - Dawn of Fantasy had more in common that this.
There are some things that bothering me.

#1. First of all the Drought. The tides in the game seems to be really annoying and weird. I am dealing with a severe drought problem, half my farms are dried out and the lakes are empty. this is going on for 4 days in a row now and only got worser.

#2. The combat is a bit odd. I get it that it is a freemium game but paying for a 1 time fight upgrade (like flaming arrows or an extra mercenary unit) is really stupid and unneccesary. I know you can craft bracelets to use them too but that take ages so no one would waste their time on that.

#3. Construction speed is odd. You don't build a whole city in one minute and demolish it in 10 minutes.

#4. As last I want to compliment the Mods on the Forum and support. They are really active and helpfull.

reviewText: There were days when I thought of Creative Assembly as developers who not only value, but also love their client-base, us Total War gamers. But then there was the biggest ever beta test of Rome 2, it lasted a year. reviewText:
Firstly this is not the traditional Total War game so do not go in expecting that; it never claimed to be the full blown experience that you get with the latest masterpiece. It does however have something else to offer and that is a mobile or quick game when a long campaign on the latest Total War is just not possible.

The essence of Total War is there but made more accessible in a number of ways. Being cross platform is just a start but I do believe the actual mechanics of the game are easier to understand for those who do not have the time to invest in or concentration span for the main series. This game is a pick up and play kingdom building experience with combat, level progression and upgrades.

Would I recommend the game; well yeah it is Free to Play, playable, nice enough graphics which any hardware could probably handle, audio is good but not sure about the speech at the beginning. Don't get me wrong there are still a few issues that need to be addressed but nothing major. One game mechanic that may annoy some people is the lowering and raising of land near water; it annoys me sometimes :)

When this game is on tablet it will be great I think as having Total War on the go is a good thing. Used to carry a heavy laptop around so I could play the main Total War games on the go but that is just not practical now I have a desktop. This game is good for when you don't have too much time to play or just want to give yourself a break from more demanding games of the franchise.

reviewText:
Well how can i put this Its very much like a mobile game but is very enjoyable

but really i am going to write about something that noone wants to touch on and thats wether or not this game is pay to win like 90% of  reviews here on steam say it is

1st saying a game is pay to win implies you are paying for an advantage that no other F2P player cannot achieve without putting money into the game

This is false

sure you can put 100 bucks in and have an army that has all the upgrades (best possible melee and ranged upgrades and armor bonus's

but can somone who is playing the game for free (liek me) achieve all these things without money?

yes

i can have axemen greataxes and crossbows and better artillery without paying a dime it just times TIME and EFFORT like most F2P games with mircrotransactiosn would force you to do

though CA i would prefer that you guys allow at least 1 blacksmith PER castle be allowed to craft it still takes time to craft and limiting to 1 blacksmith overall is just toooooo slow

but anyways this game has alot of fun elements........ i have almost 100 hours on it and after really wiht all this experience i am gonna say the game is NOT pay to win it just takes time to get to where you need to be rather than where you want to be

CA i understand the Limit on the Greatsword Knights but cmon there has to be a line drawn somewhere with all the limiting on the stronger Troops becuase your AI has multiples of these Troops and i have no problem beating them at all really

so my opinion is Drop the Limit on Greatswords/axes but keep the limit on crossbows if there is one becuase they are just silly Strong

reviewText:
A pay to win, reputation destroying game. Nice going Creative Assembly.

Pros:
Voice acting
Cons:
Very boring battles, no strategy involved
Have to log on every 2-3 hours, to complete 1 task, before closing the game
Pay to win, the best units cost a lot of in game gold, which is impossible to earn enough
Very buggy, especially with dams you have to build
Basically everything else in the game

I understand this is still in beta, but unless they remove the whole pay to win aspect, ie, charging a lot of microtransactions for this game, then this is a complete waste of time. I've heard people saying, its not pay to win if you play enough". Please tell me how it isn't pay to win

reviewText:
The game has very good intentions as well as a fantastic concept! It falls short largely due to monetization and the ridiculous amount of time it takes to gather a fairly small amount of ressources.

I enjoy what they were trying to do... The concept of the game is solid, and shines brightly despite heavy monetization. The servers are pretty bad, the wait is bad and it's hardly worth what you're waiting for! I do hope they balance waits and gains in such a way that a free-to-play player can make proper headway like Creative Assembly claims they can.

For now, I can't recommend this game. Blatant money-grabs with poor servers and rewards makes for a frustrating experience. The qualms are fairly easy to fix, but will they bother?

reviewText:
This is not a Total War game, it is just a pay2win mobile game. By hearing the title Total War I expect three things, a campaign map, epic scale battles and extended use of strategy. Unfortunately,I saw none of those main features in this game. Instead, it is mainly a city building game.

There are the main resources that you use for costructing buildings and recruiting units. However, some processes take hours to be finished and you have to use gold which can be collected by two ways, or by completing missions and objectives, (which are just to build a number of specific buildings ,fight battles or to conquer new parts of the map, ) or by spending real money. The only thing that I personally liked was the teraforming feature because lakes and rivers can affect both positively and negatively the production of some resources.

The battles are just a huge dissapointment because they are not huge and they have no strategy at all. Furthermore, you have to deploy your units on three lines , with maximum three units per line, they march towards the enemy and you have to just order charge at the right moment to have some bonus and there are some special abilities that give advantage to your units for a short time. Except from that, your units cannot move on a horizontal axis to help their fellow soldiers, they can attack only on the units that are in front of them. And the worst part is that the battles last for a few seconds.

The visuals are great for a mobile strategy game. The map and the battles are 3d and generally the game does not look ugly. Instead, it looks quite beautiful. The audio is decent except from one part, the voice acting of the soldiers is the same from Rome II and no matter the fact that the British used to be christians back then you may hear them say praise the gods". That shows how much some people from CA probably cared for their game by throwing in it files without checking them.

reviewText:
Played 4 hours so far. Sadly not at all what I expected.

I have to admit I downloaded because I have played all TW games since Shogun 1 and I belong to those who enjoy Rome 2 and Attila, even so it is raining DLC.

But the Game has sadly nothing to do with strategy or any other game of the TW line.
It is a of the shelf clone of most “strategy games” on Android or other mobile devices. Build a “base” that produces resources, improve resource output over time and create and “army”. The army consist of a handful of units that slowly improve. The battles are the real letdown – a fallback to the old column-attacker games. You have three columns with troops. You can shift your units from column to column or change them from front row to second row or third row. You have very little influence on the combat at all – just a defense, offense and ranged weapons bonus you canm activate from time to time.

Right now the game shines in no area at all. The aspect that I don’t like most is the glacial speed of the game. If you are not willing to invest money – and I am not at this stage – you have to wait until resources are harvested and your undying army units have regained health.

All in all an off the shelf Skinner box that has no special merits right now.

Somewhere between 4/10 (because upset they used the TW branding on it) and a 6/10 if you are into click and wait games on Android or other mobile devices.

It's main saving grace is that it's free, at least that was something they got right!\n\nThe interface is clunky and unintuitive, the combat is pretty dull. I would not recommend you play this game.

reviewText:
Not terrible but certainly not good. Falls down on the use of the total war name most of all in my opinion (explained below). It's a tablet game and nothing more, if this were a play store or Itunes review the score would be very different. It's not a PC game, f2p or not, end of discussion. But if Sega insist on offering it as a PC game I shall review it as one.

5/10

I did have to think quite a lot about whether I could recommend this game and while it’s not a bad game per se it certainly isn’t a good game at the moment ( I appreciate it’s still in beta and a lot could change) . In fact to be fair to this game as a free-2-play it’s not too bad and miles ahead of Stronghold: kingdoms in both art style and mechanics.

On the positive side I thought that the building and settlement creation were quite well done though they are a little basic. Kudos to the team for pretty excellent terrain height, excavation and water mechanic programing, it really helps to create this felling that the world itself can be shaped to suit your needs. The time required for building and resource gathering was pretty good, not obscenely long as in most free-2-plays (read as free-2-wait). On top of this you can even find and mine premium currency allowing any player no matter how stingy to gain some of the advantages. In fact if the game was purely the build section then I would actually recommend it.

There are however massive issues with the battle system. And by massive issues I mean JESUS CHRIST WHY DID YOU THINK THIS WAS A GOOD IDEA? Yeah that level of bad. I do have to admit that most of my issues with the combat are simply that it is difficult to accept calling this a total war game. I am a die-hard fan of the series (hell I even like empire) and like many total war fans I love the complexity of tactics one can to utilize to win. The battles of Battles: Kingdom seem to have stripped all this away to be replaced with clicking to charge at the right time….what?..... WHAT?.... HOW HAVE YOU TURNED YOUR COMBAT INTO QUICK TIME EVENTS? QTEs in total war now, along with day one dlc you’d be forgiven for thinking EA had bought CA. That said Sega aren’t much better look what they did to sonic. I have't played Shogun 2 Battles but i see that the combat in that is turn based, why didn't they keep that? sure its not total war but at least it's still tactical not ♥♥♥♥ING QTEs!!! But my issues with the battles don’t stop there. I have a few other problems with it as well like why is there a cool down for ordering archers to fire? One unit fires on one enemy unit and I have to wait a good few seconds before I can order an entirely separate unit of archers to fire on an entirely separate unit of archers. The orders system is a nice idea but I don’t think it is well realised. The unit special abilities and general abilities from Rome 2 would’ve been a better style of system and each ability has advantages and disadvantages meaning that they are a tactical choice. The orders on the others hand you just spam every time the cool down timer is over.

How did they mess this up so badly?

Not something that gets my personal recommendation but if you’re a looking for a well-balanced f2p and you don’t consider this an affront to the good name total war then it’s not all that bad under the surface.

reviewText: Now, despite my rating of this game I actually really have enjoyed my time in it. And for what it is its not a bad playthrough. But just some disturbing trends in it almost completely turn me off of it. Needing to pay gold (the games cash to coin currency) in order to unlock better units, such as spearmen. Though there is alternative options, such as forging them, not only do they not work 100% of the time, but you also dont even unlock it till later in the game. I was also rather bothered by the resources system, resources collected drop tiles which you need to click on in order to collect said resource. Needing to click on the tiles in order to collect them means you need to play the game in order to advance at all, and for the game being what it is I think its a dumb feature that would be immensely improved on simply by removing it. Also stone is very difficult to collect in large quantities, while you will never have any problems with wood or food, spending stone will usually leave you scraping the bottom of the barrel at early levels. And the combat system, while not being bad, isn't nearly good enough to hold my attention for long enough to keep my constantly playing in order to collect resources so I can advance.

reviewText:
After playing this for some time, and ignoring all other reviews so that I can play the game thoroughly enough to form my own opinion, I can say that the game is not just pay2win / progress.. it's also grow-old2win / progress.

PvP review:-

Do you want a chance to get to the top without putting in any money at all? you won't get it here.. why you ask? well for pvp you can call in extras" like fire arrows or better melee power to even calling in another unit to help you out.. the catch is that it costs gold OR using up a bracelet which can be crafted... the downside is that the crafting takes 80 hours to produce and you're not guaranteed to get any bracelets at all.

Take for example an average outcome with "master crafting" (which is more expensive than normal crafting) you may get 5 bracelets in 80 hours
date:
your top pvp opponent does not need this as he just pays 3 gold for his advantage each and every time.. that puts you in one of three camps.

1) pay2win the same as your opponent for an equal chance of winning (if you don't take stats into account).

2) use one of the bracelets it's taken you almost 4 days to make and get a win or two granting you a few places higher in the ranks.

or

3) save up a huge amount of bracelets so that you can get the advantage in pvp the same as the pay2win folk do 100% of the time.

This leaves you be one of 2 players
recommended: either Pay2win or grow-old2win (by which time no one will be playing anymore / game will be shut down).\n\nYou may enjoy this if you just want to attack AI and you only have about 5 - 10 minutes every 5 hours to play (as this game was very much aimed at the mobile market) or pay for everything
voteText: unfair and a complete grind.\n"

reviewText: Now, despite my rating of this game I actually really have enjoyed my time in it. And for what it is its not a bad playthrough. But just some disturbing trends in it almost completely turn me off of it. Needing to pay gold (the games cash to coin currency) in order to unlock better units, such as spearmen. Though there is alternative options, such as forging them, not only do they not work 100% of the time, but you also dont even unlock it till later in the game. I was also rather bothered by the resources system, resources collected drop tiles which you need to click on in order to collect said resource. Needing to click on the tiles in order to collect them means you need to play the game in order to advance at all, and for the game being what it is I think its a dumb feature that would be immensely improved on simply by removing it. Also stone is very difficult to collect in large quantities, while you will never have any problems with wood or food, spending stone will usually leave you scraping the bottom of the barrel at early levels. And the combat system, while not being bad, isn't nearly good enough to hold my attention for long enough to keep my constantly playing in order to collect resources so I can advance.

reviewText:
This game looks promising when you first try and play it.
You will make some mistakes in the start, as the tutorials are none existent.
Managing a kingdom seem fun and battles seem alright.
But the further you play, you’ll start to notice certain things.

The battles are unbalanced mess. Normal battles can be easy to win, but at times you’ll get your ♥♥♥ handed to you. Challenging battles can be just that, challenging and you’ll win them barely. But at times the enemy will slaughter you before you can say “What the-!”

The mobile version of this game is horrible. Cause it barely works.
In Steam and for mobile, the loading times can be very long. But the mobile takes the cake.
Sometimes your actions don’t register on your mobile version. You can do a lot of stuff and at first it seems that everything is fine. Then you suddenly start to think “Hmm…somethings wrong” and when you go to Steam to check ( if you can ) you’ll see that every action you did on the mobile, didn’t register.
And at times it can crash or just kick you out of the game completely.

The game mechanics are questionable too. Like crafting, which takes insane amount of time to do. A lot of resources to make. And when your crafting is finished and fails. You just want to throw your phone on the wall, because you wasted 60 hours of work and 125 crafting materials for nothing. Brilliant.

I only tried the game cause it’s free to play and- well… I’m just glad I didn’t waste any money for this game. Cause I would be ♥♥♥♥♥♥.
And my friend is a Total War fanatic, who wanted to play something Total War related with me and haven’t tried this game before.
Probably won’t come as a shocker, but he didn’t like this game either.

reviewText:
Ive been playing for a few hours now. I see how the game is supposed to be, but they dont seem to be able to reach that, the gathering times are too long, the resource respawning is too long, and the AI in battles can be realy hard to beat when they have 3 units of mercs and i have mostly Levies.

It could probably become one of the best games on the mobile market for this kind of game, if i didnt have to wait an hour to get my wood from a tree then wait for tree stumps to vanish, then grass to grow, then trees to grow, all this work will probably take a day or 3 and for what? 20 wood? i need around 500 wood to be able to UPGRADE that wood cutter.

Then again. it is a good game, its nice to be able to freely expand my town/city while having to worry about rivers and hills to be able to build my town. the combat is 200x better than all the other bad/weird mobile games (except games like Clash of Clans wich have a pretty good combat system for Mobile games)

I would not recomend this if your hoping for it to be a conquer the world with a massive army" like in the other Total wars. Ofcourse i wouldnt call this a Total war game if i was CA though.

I would recomend it thought to people that feel they want something to do while they are bored or have nothing better to do. Dont think that when you install this you will be met by being able to build hundreds of buildings in under a minute

reviewText:
Despite this game have the Battles-Part in the name I decided to give it a try. After all the game looked good this time around and the city-building seemed interesting. This sadly led to me wasting around 2 hours of my life.

Now let's take a look at the good points first:

-The graphics are great. From the landscape to the buildings and even the units (not that you will have a lot of time to
look at them)

-You have the ability to build some truly impressive cities. it won't be easy and it sure as hell won't be anytime soon that
you have one, but in the end the player is (theoretically) able to do it.

Sadly the downsides easily outweight those good sides:

-The combat is lane based. I personally HATE those kinds anyway but I thought Hey
date: maybe CA actually made it good"
recommended: \nbut the answers was a loud all-encompassinge "Nope". It's just run-of.the-mill lane-combat. No flanking
voteText: a very limited amount of troops
helpfulPercent:
both in numbers and in variation and in general all
the suckage that is lane-combat.

-Upgrading your units takes a lot of time. And I mean a LOT of it. The first upgrade for any of the basic attributes costs
20 points
votesHelpful:
the next 40. Now I dont know if I'm just bad or what but I got around 7-12 per fight. That wouldn't be so bad
if the fight themselves would be fun (they are not) and if there were no freaking enforced break after every battle (if
they were harmed). You can of course skip it but that requires hard gold aka real money.

-The game in general is just slow
votesTotal: by the way: did you know that grass grows faster than this games plays? Okay that\nwas exaggerated but the fact remains that the amount of time you spend waiting is ridiculous. Gathering ressources\nfrom random spots takes 10 minutes which is okay
votesFunny:
same goes for excevating stone but gathering wood and wood
takes days and this time I'm not even kidding. Wood and crops both take 8 hours to chop/gather and then another 10
hours for crops and up to 2 (or 1 and a half) to regrow. Now it wouldn't be so bad if you would at least get a decent
amount but you only get 10 per field... 10! Though you can once again skip all this waiting with gold... hooray.

My verdict is:  BEST GAME OF ALL TIME 13/10!!! *shot*  Stay away from it

reviewText:
Since I started playing this with the expectations most of the reviews had given me I find this game quite enjoyable. One can't expect the ordinary Total War game, because it isn't. It is an online rts game and that's why I don't find it strange or annoying with long building times.

I would say this game is a mix between Total War, Civilization and Stronghold Kingdoms. Sure there are some bugs but it's still in beta and it's running better than I though it would on my laptop. So far I haven't felt that it's a pay-2-win game and that is also positive, since there are games like this out there that you can't progress in if you aren't paying a ton of money.

All in all I think it's a good game, and since it's free you should at least try it out for yourself and make your own opinion!

reviewText: I do recommend this game if you're looking for a strategic battlefield simulation game. It has everything you need, and an easy levelling system, easy resources, and a tough setup that will keep you on your toes. Water works well into the terrain, and the layout of the buildings are well-done. The only downside I could find to this game is the PvP. You can be a low level, and it will literally put you with someone 7 levels higher than you just because they have a rank close to yours. This is extremely unfair and should be fixed, but I'm sure they're MUCH too busy to do that. Otherwise, a good game. I do recommend it.

reviewText: It is poorly made game. With many of the mechanics of the game being shody. There absolute no tactics require it more of how lucky you are and if you can play the system against it self. Resource gathering takes forever each resource gathering takes 20 mins only get 20 of said resources at times and you lose 10 resource if do the reap all benefit causing it to be at 8 hr wait.  To upgrade building take more resources to upgrade than to build new buildings. example building a lumber camp takes about 50x resouces of each food and silver. To upgraded it cost about 500x of resources of food and silver. the conversion rate is for upgrade to each builidng is about 100% of orginal for level 2. It get worse at third level and four level converison it becomes 1000% at level 3 to 10000% at level 4 of the orginal resource cost. Missions can go to relative easy to insanely hard and with enemie two to three level higher than your units even at easy calculation levels also mission quest have units that would require you to spend gold to obtain better units and equipment until you able to craft them at level 21. Crafting is really cheap system making nearly impossible to craft any items or unit as it take insane amount of craft material to reach levels of weapons example crafting a level 1 longsword  would take you 35 craft material and 1000 silver to complete for each stage and there are five stage for each weapon or unit making extremely time consuming and it would be cheaper to buy the said equipment with gold for the time wasted also the chances or earning gold is extremely hard as well.  The game force you spend gold in order to win the most easy of battles. Even if you have units equip to max and level to maxed you have 70-90% chance of losing each mission encounter if you just sat watch your unit fight easy mission.  If you actually do something such use the tactics and skill that units have you have maybe of 50-60% chance of losing on the easiest missions rating. Dueling system does not always work. It took me forever to wait for one duel and they pitted me against player rank six level higher than me with units several time stronger. If they can fix the resource gathering problems and lower the amount it take to level up to next level at acceptable levels then it would better. Also there unit caps on special units that you are allowed to build while with missions quest does not have these unit caps thus you can go against army of knights all at level three which really sucks.  Sorry for the long rant. I still play the game since invest a large amount of money into the game.

reviewText:
I screamed when I played my first battle in this game, wait, nevermind, I didnt play any battles, I just watched a one.

This game has none of the features of a Total War game. There is no total war, the battles are disgusting in how they foul the image of previous titles, and there are no kingdoms, just glorified estates. This game could have been a quirky simple, mainstream version of total war for free, but all it is, is Clash of Clans with a respected name. This game screams for your money, and while i expected that a free to play gme would need it's way of earning money,this is just disgraceful. This game does not deserve the name it bears, and to watch this game explain its mechanics to me like I'm a brain damaged horse, is to see the horrible future for this franchise.

I for one wanted a Total War game that had the same micro transactions as Team Fortress, or DOTA, a game that is simplified but still has an enjoyable, simple combat system, wih small armies, but soldiers that matter, that you'd care about. But unfortuntely, that sentence doesnt have enough $$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$$

reviewText: I have been playing this game for some 17.6 hours over several weeks( whic is constantly upgrading and waiting), I think it is extremely difficult to understand alot of the game mechanics. the water fluidity mechanics for example can completely ruin your entire map if you try to excavate and change your terain to build over the winter. come spring everything can flood before you realize your mistake. the crafting system is absurd in the fact of the amount of resources per crafting stage..yes 5 crafting stages per item with more materials then could reasonably be put into a shield for example. Combat missions for begining players is at best a slaughter, which is designed to make you pay for gold to heal your units..pay to play..the map is not big enough to correctly build roads between the first new area you can win/pay tribute to gain. By the time you try to build roads adjusting the terrain to do so, you ruin the correct aspect of farming/herding/grazing mechanics, and oh yeah dont forget the flooding. It took me along time to build/rebuild buildings to locate them properly within the given terrain..its bearily possible because you place x amount of buildings before you level which unlocks the buildings you should have placed corectly the first time..woops wasted time and resouces again..then to realize the harbor once you can make one doesnt work right because the ships cant get up the river to the fish..lol..demolish.. rebuild terain..try to make a river to reach them..oops you cant lower terain uphill to the level of the fish..ugh..I hope the game has a wipe upon release because I really would do so much better now that I know what I should have done if the information would have been available to learn how beforehand!\nThe game has great potential if some better information was available to new players before they make game ending mistakes..flood entire map for example..hard to recover from..with no option to delete and start anew.

reviewText: Rating: 6/10
voteText: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
TL;DR at the bottom.

People need to realise that this is a game designed for tablet / mobile thus not a title between all the other Total War games but an offshot for a completely different platform. Imagine playing the latest Total War on tablet, not happening.
How can you tell? Controls. Mouse only, no keybindings.

Mobile games are coming to steam! So are console games! Deal with it! To start a hate train because a game seemed to come to the wrong neighbourhood" is unsightly. They can do their part on steam too but you are not forced in any way to play them.

This game is also "F2P" (Depending on your definition) which with most certainty includes microtransactions like most F2P titles (Big suprise there). Being F2P also creates paywalls which are either non scalable because the content behind it is exclusively for paying users or tough but not impossible to reach for players who do not want to spend real money. And in the end becomes a slowpaced game for everyone who decides not to spend money.

First of all I'd like to dispel some of the false or lacking information on which most reviews are based creating a maelstrom of bad reviews from players fresh out of the tutorial.

The most popular : Harvesting wheat / felling trees -> 8 hours waiting
After building your farm wheat fields start to appear around it
date:
depending on the distance to water the time until they are able to be harvested differs.
After the wheat is finally harvestable you are given TWO CHOICES:
1. Harvest a single spot : 20 min. = 20 units
or
2. Harvest ALL spots : 8 hours = 10 units / spot
As you can see option no. 2 is the worst possible choice.
If this is the reason you quit playing and gave the game a bad review then you should have paid more attention to what you are doing instead of causing a temper tantrum for no reason.
It is quite a waiting game at the beginning
recommended: but every sane gamer would not stare at the monitor waiting for the counter to drop to zero
hoursPlayed:
that's why this is more of an inbetween games game.

The most concerning : Pay to win / Paywall (Paying users exclusive content)
I think we all can agree that in a situation where you pit equally skilled players against one another
voteText: that the one who can pay real money to give him an edge in combat will most definetely win if the game is not heavily RNG-based.\nHowever the real question here is: Is the equally skilled player condemned to never overcome this hurdle even with zeal and competetive spirit? The answer to that is : He can
helpfulPercent: with time.\nLet me explain:\nThere are NO paying users exclusive : Buildings / Units / Buffs / Equipment
votesHelpful: every player has the same selection and arsenal. Unlike other mobile games where the best buildings and units are exclusively obtainable through real money.\nAll players do not have acess to everything on the get go. You need to reach a certain level regardless wether you want to pay or not to have buildings (and their corresponding units) unlocked. Every military building comes with a selection of 3 to 4 different units depending on the building.\nExample : You build your first stable and it can house only one mounted unit. After building your stable you choose which one you want. (F2P ALERT) The first two of the three units you can choose without any hitch (100% free)
votesTotal: however the third is behind a real money paywall (That shook you a little
votesFunny:
right?). But against all odds you are able to "craft" the third unit and kick out the one currently stationed (no money paid).
Those units are statwise superior than the other but not unobtainable for non paying users.
As for Buffs and Equipment those can also be crafted like military units and given to those or used on the battlefield.

As for the game itself. It is pretty slowpaced but steadily gains velocity as you progress. You start off with 1 of 6 regions and you have a restriction of how many buildings you can mantain within this region. This restriction gradually decreases the more regions you liberate and castles you upgrade within each region. Effectively increasing your playtime each session. I do not want to venture any further into the building system and the little tricks therein
commentsCount: because a little trial and error doesnt hurt.\n\nThe tutorial is rather short and gives you the basics of the basics but not all the vital information you desperately need. In my opinion this is a bad choice of tutorial
column16: instead of having tutorial pieces pop up when you need them
column17: say changing seasons
column18: new buildings
column19: new units
column21:
small events etc. they leave you out to fend for yourself and figure it out on your own.
Along with the tutorial the tooltips also lack information as well as numbers.
Tooltips need a desperate overhaul and the tutorial needs to be more than just an introduction to the basics of basics. To counter a lack of information a compedium of such would have been a nice way to make wating somehow enjoyable.

The combat is a squad based rock-paper-scissors system (if that makes any sense). Every unit consists of multiple soldiers and counter or is countered by another unit. Lance > Rider > Shield > Archer > Lance > and so on. Additionaly armor is a factor Mace > leather + chain
column23: in the beginning the two facing units charge each other to engage in close combat depending on your timing
column24: you do heavy charge damage before the brawl begins or none at all (pre-emptive strike). But wait! There's more!\nEvery unit can get one of two abilites purchased through experience acquired through battle. Making your units more diverse and useful in certain situation. For example switching your shield units with a your mounted units which are engaged with lance units (rock-paper-scissors
column25: remember?) to avoid certain death for your horsemen.\nTo top it all of you can have in your 9-squad army up to 3 and at least 1 siege unit. Ranging from ballistaes
column26: trebuchets or mangonels. Ballistaes hit only enemy units for moderate damage
column27: instantly killing weak armored targets. Trebuchets hit all units for a good amount of damage. Mangonels leave the area they hit burning and damaging any and all units that remain in this area. Every siege unit act as an ability with their own innate cooldown before you can use them again. But if you have 3 siege units and 6 fighting units and on the other hand your oppenent has 9 fighting units which disperse your 6 quite fast you have lost even with the siege units still intact und unscathed. (I don't think you can actually damage / destroy siege units)\nQuite the arsenal and not as simple a battlesystem I dare say.\nAfter every battle your units need time to recuperate depending on how wounded they are 10 to 20 min. or if unscathed not at all. However you cannot engage in another battle while a unit in your army is still recuperating. Yes
column28: you can skip waiting with a little bit of moneyflow but if you are eager to fight battle after battle it can become very expensive and you should play another Total War game.\nThe experience your units gain can be used to either upgrade the unit itself thus adding more soldiers to this unit
column31: armor rating or charge damage. Or as already mentioned purchase one of two abilites for this unit which may turn the tide of battle.\n\nTL;DR: It's a F2P inbetween-games-(tablet)game with no content locked behind a paywall (no paying user exclusives). Paying players cannot exceed the limits of a non-paying player. Slowpaced at the start with steadily increasing session lengths. Lack of information may result in uneffecient use of terrain
column32: buildings or units. Not a game for the impatient.\n\nThis will get downvoted to hell because those who do
column33: are either those you didn't grasp the concept of the game or jumped on the hate train for the lulz."

reviewText:
Overall its one of the best free to play town building game. Has some great concepts such as game effecting seasons and terrain modifying. If you like a slight mixture of civ 5, past total war games, and stronghold then you may like this game.

But I do think it would be a more popular game/ better to play if it was buy to play or if it leaned less on paying for gold to actually get/do stuff. It could focus more on advisors,perks,customization with the in game purchases rather than pay some gold to buy a unit or to get tons of resources to upgrade a building/ craft a unit. Also a sort of info panel on units, buildings, game concepts, etc. would help. Because sometimes I would find myself building in an area where it will not function or building something like the knights manor where you can only have one unit of that type.

Pros:
Casual (if you like that)
Good Concepts
Good Environment
Customization of units,town,environment, etc.
Quest system

Cons:
Casual (if you dont like that)
Some things cost rediculous amounts of silver/resources to upgrade, sort of forcing the player to grind for days or to use gold
No info panel

Summary: You should give it a try, though depending on who you are you will probably uninstall it. It is in beta so you can't really hate on it because it is still being developed and does require info from the community to help out devs. To an extent you can play the game f2p but there will eventually be moments where you will end up spending gold to advance. It is built more for mobile device users who usually do spend $ for in game currency rather than pc gamers.

I will probably continue to play it. But I do hope that it improves and leans more towards pc user gameplay rather than casual mobile players.

reviewText:
I really enjoy the terraforming, city planning,  and the battle. but the games really need a restart button.

Should not try to rush the game, but play it in an interval of period of time.

battle only takes around 2 minutes. As you progress, the battle become more difficult and you have to figure out ways to counter the enemy.

Terraforming and building city is great. such as drying out an entire lake to redo irragation and fishing pond or forest land. takes forever, but the final outcome is supprising. The resource ouput increases without any battles.

City planning is difficult, because the game is still in beta version and their are no tips or help wiki. You learn by mistake.

At the start focus on controlling the first two regions by building up an army and a battle strategy. After that,  I went into complete domestic planning (farming, controlling river, quarry...) to increase resouce output like food, stones and woods.

Silver can easily be earn by battle, so do not waste too much time on that resource.

reviewText:
Total War Battles series for mobile plattforms.

Most people seem to confuse the Battle series which is a more casual approach towards mobile plattforms for the full blown Total War games. This is not the case. There are two games in the Battle series. The old Shogun and now this Kingodm. These are ment to compete with other mobile freemium strategy games out there on tablets etc.

Kingdom is by far the best game Ive ever tried in this category and I look very much forward to have it on my iPad. The really neat thing this time around is that you can play the game on all plattforms. PC, Tablet etc. and that is a great feature for a mobile game.

For its category it has great depth and immersion and Im totally hooked and played close to 40 hours of the Open Beta with 3 characters in parallell. Of course, being a Beta you must expect a lot of issues and be patient.

Looking very much forward to having this on my iPad :).

reviewText:
I've played this game a few hours now and have mixed feelings.
It playes like a browser multiplayer RTS, except that the city building is much better, everything has a timer.

Pro:
- Like the city building and resource management system
- GFX is good for this kind of game
- Like the easy, but strategic combat


Cons:
- Miss seing other players on the map
- Miss interacting with other players (other than duels)
- Where's the alliance system?
- Should be player controlled land and cities to conquer (Have not seen any yet)


They have created a good plattform from which to expand with many features. It's war, so let us wage war agains other players too!

I'm gonna keep playing and expanding my territory for many hours yet, but what happend when the six regions is mine? What's the end-game goal then? You should try this game out and let's hope they expand with more features tuned toward player interaction :)

reviewText:
It's hard to get into the city building part because it's sooooooo slooooooow paced.  Wait ages to get a pittance from your resource supply nodes.

Battles are a joke.  Minimal control over your units once battle starts.  Global cooldowns* applied to multiple units makes any kind of on the fly deployment reorganization or [ranged] target change a huge hassle.


Unless you throw money at it, I can't see this as anything more than a minor distraction once or twice a day(like while you're on the can).  The four hours play time I have/[had at time of review], is about 10-12 sessions because there is so little to do.



* They don't seem to apply to AI though.  I had one enemy end unit move two times in a row, to the other end slot.  It was a cavalry unit so I had my spears lined up to them before the battle.  I started my move before their first move was over, but before my units were finished swapping, they were already starting their next swap.  Before my move cooldown was up, the fighting had begun.

reviewText:
Most reviews here are (understandably) from people who dislike Free to Play games. However, if you are into that kind of thing - hopefully this will be somewhat useful.

TLDR:
- The game plays more like ANNO than it does total war. It's a great casual game for people that like building little cities, and the grind isn't prohibitive in the way many free games are. It's definitely worth playing if you enjoy casual games.

What makes it better than most casual games:
- You begin with enough resources and always have enough to be actively playing, not waiting. There are things to be done on an hourly basis to manage your cities.
- There are new buildings to be unlocked for the first few days of playing, and it doesn't take too long to keep unlocking them. There is no way to pay to speed this up either.
- The terrain can be manipulated, to give you more feeling of control in shaping your kingdom
- The game relies more on placement of resources than just having stuff"
date: there is skill and thought to go into each building placement.\n- The water has dynamic flow
recommended: meaning you have to build proper channels that bring water from uphill regions to your farms. This is a major element of the game
hoursPlayed: and messing it can literally flood your cities.\n- The combat is a minigame
voteText:
where you have some extra control over how your units fight. It's not just a numbers game on building a big army.

Where it is still lacking:
- Forests only grow from existing ones
helpfulPercent: and can easily be cut down
votesHelpful: making it extremely easy to snooker yourself into a resource-dead map\n- There isn't a great deal of unit variety
votesTotal:
especially without using gold (premium currency that can be generated VERY slowly if you dislike paying)
- There is a severe lack of explanation/wiki data on what buildings are/cost/etc. before having built one. There are instances you can waste a lot of resoures finding out that things don't work as assumed (e.g. only being able to have one "medium cavalry" unit in total - even after building a second stables.

All in all
votesFunny: I'd definitely recommend this to anybody that wants a game to spend 15 minutes every hour or so keeping their land in order. It's not for regular total war fans at all - but the creative assembly have made (in my opinion) an extremely polished
commentsCount: fun and non-restrictive F2P title. You can absolutely have a great time without ever spending a penny."

reviewText:
All the negative reviews for this game compare it to all the other total war games, such as Shogun, Rome, Medieval, etc. Compared to them, yes, this game IS not good. However, this is a MOBILE game (At least not at the moment). This game was made to be played on a tablet as well a computer. As a mobile game, this game is great. So before I say more, I will be treating this as a MOBILE game in this review.

Battles:

Pros:
Great detail

Simple and fun

Still requires the use of tactics and stretegy

Can be very challenging at points

Many different units to the game, from mercenaries to vikings


Cons:

Only 1 unit against 1 unit in close combat

Cannot destroy artillery

Recharging orders to shoot, move, or stop shooting- probably the worst part.

No flanking



Campaign/Empire building


Pros:

Great detail

Expanding your kingdom is really fun. You get to conquer territories and expand you empire usint tiles, which allow you to create your own cities.


Cons:
Wait times for building, gathering, etc can be a very long time (12 hours is the longest I have seen so far.) But compared to other free mobile games, wait times are really not that bad. *cough* CoC *cough*


This game is definitly one of the best free to play strategy games I have played. If you like the genre, this is a game you should try out. The only thing I would change is to make some things not require currency (Gold) that requires micro-transactions" (I qoute that because you CAN get gold without paying for it
date: fairly easily compared to other games) But other then that
recommended: Im having a great time with the game.\n"

reviewText:
Now I love(d) the Total War series, I've played everything from Rome I to Rome II, and I can say, that as a long time TW player, I don't think this is a good Total War game, infact I question if it should even be associated with TW. But, as a video game player in general, I think this a decent game. Sure they expect you to pay microtransactions, but I havent payed a single micro transaction and my game is going fairly smoothyl, this isn't a waiting game, this is a game that you should play for about 10-20 mins a day, go about your business and maybe check up on your Breton town with your electronic device. If you expect, a grand strategy, amazing, award winning, strategy game that can keep you entertained for hours on end, than you will be in for a sore dissappointment. But if you play it for what it is, than it will be a perfectly good game to spend some time playing.

=======Pros=======
-Battles
-Graphics
-City / Town management
-Territory Conquest

=======Cons=======
-No Byzantines (Yea, I was kinda dissappointed we could only be Bretons. Can't even be Saxon or Norse, just Bretons... Hey I guess you could be King Arthur though)

Now some of you might think that there has to be more problems to the game than 'No Byzantines.' Yea... not really, it's a free game and if you want you can put a few dollars into micropurchases, these micropurchases aren't actually needed to play the game though. Oh, and did I mention, IT'S FREE. There is nothing wrong with this game, people don't like it because it doesn't fit in the 'Grand Strategy' category that most TW games do. So, there is no reason, not to get this game. So get it, play it, hate it, love it, I don't care. This game gives me much more hope in the TW title than Attila (That over priced DLC that they call a game) ever will. Just because, this is a unique game that is fun and you can kill some time on.

Comments are welcome. (Within reason)

reviewText:
This is very much an adroid/ios mobile rts freemium game, the typical expectations of such include but are not limited to long wait times to build stuff and the further you go the faster you can expand because you will be making so much more income at a time than in the beginning.  You can do absolutely everything for free it will just take longer, which is typical of a mobile freemium game.

The game is quite aesthetically pleasing and the little nuances of weather and what the different seasons do to the land scape are a very nice touch.  The combat is pretty straight forward with some tactic and foresight required, very rock paper scissors with some buffs and debuffs you can use but only up to 3 buffs/debuffs at a time that you can unlock as you go.

All in all it makes for a great mobile game, something to check in on or play for a few minutes to an hour a day, but not a good PC game due to the amount of time it takes to do things and the style of play, I dont think it was ever originally intended to be a PC game and was the original design of it to be a mobile game, in which case I believe it excels very well.  As such I recommend this game and am patiently waiting for it to come to android, however if this had been originally designed for PC(which I know it is not) then i would be agreeing with the sea of negativity this game seems to have on steam.

reviewText:
This is not your usual Total War game
The PVP is PAY2WIN and the AI is as hard as it gets
BUT
It is a nice casual experience and you don't HAVE to spend money to get most of the features
It feels a lot like playing Settlers or Anno, which I personally like

PROs
+ Nice and slim GFX and UI
+ Terraforming (although you can screw yourself pretty easily by flooding everything)
+ Rock, Paper, Scissor battle mechanics with special abilities
+ Unit 'customization' in form of XP, skills and abilities
+ Random special events and Quests
+ Gold currency can be earned without spending money
+ Multi platform support in the future

Cons
- Long wait times and micromanagement
- Early on most AI battles feel really unbalanced
- Slow resources
- PVP is almost unplayable because of P2W
- Most customization options and special units are overtly expensive

Would still recommend for casual players
Although this is NOT comparable to the Total War Experience

This game is excellent.

The negative reviews come from people expecting this game to be the strategic simulation the franchise is known for.
Kingdom's deviates from this stereotype with an easy to learn Kingdom building experience with just the right helping of simple commands to be issued during combat.

If you are a Total War fanboy then you might as well just pass it over.

reviewText:
Before i make the review, just gotta make the point that this IS NOT A TOTAL WAR MAIN INSTALLMENT, so one should not expect the main features of a Total War game.

Now into the game:

Pros:-
* Epic City Building
* Reasonable Battles
* Banner  Customisation
* Character Customisation
Cons:-
* Lots of Customisation options require Gold, a substance mainly obtained by buying it with real money
* Wait times for crops to grow and mining stone

So Overall, this game is a good free-to-play game i recomend, with only the Cons i mentioned above being the main downers for the game. It is not a full Total War, but it is great as its own game, with much potential being only in Open-Beta.

reviewText:
As far as free to play games go this one is ok, but the only reason it is good is due to it being a TOTAL WAR game. If this didn't have its title no-one would play it.

Pros:
-Adds a new spin on city builder games
-Addictive
-Not hard to get good
-competitive with friends

Cons:
-Autumn flooding is complete bull ****, you spend loads of time in summer trying to ge water through your lands and then along comes the f***fest of rain. One river overflow and 2 towns got flooded, 3 quarries, 2 farms and all of my f***ing roads were destroyed. But I can't do anything about it until winter comes to get rid of the sea in the centre of my kingdom.
-Secondly the combat is completly broken, when taking over new regions the firs two are fine, the third is hard but not impossible and then comes the fourth. All you have to do is look at the army and realise it is impossible without paying them off. It seems as if they don't want people to progress without spending their life savings for an army. Also when you go into online duels there are no matchmaking, all that happens is they put you with some random person without looking a if you spent money or your level in game. In 3 instances I have been against people who have obviously spent loads of money which means I definitely will not beat them. A couple of times I have been against people using the starting units when I have a very strong army without spending money, this system is completely broken and must be fixed.

Although it seems the cons are much greater than the pros I must still remind you it is in BETA so this game still has a while to go before it can be judged as a full game like Rome 2 was.

reviewText:
Yes, recommended: But be prepared. Essentially a Clash of Clans-esque game with the Total War logo.

Played it for about 3 days straight. First of all. To all those naysayers, and I know there are many for this game.
This game is not a traditional Total War game. It's essentially them trying out mobile games. And it's amazing, in that regard.
Then, for those people saying it's pay to play. That couldn't be farther from the true. It's the perfect homework game. Start mining, start farming, then do your homework. It is not pay to play to play, in the three days i've played, i've been doing just fine, winning online matches aplenty, rank is 16 and continuing to go down everytime I do an online match.
It's an amazing game overall, simply understand that this isn't a traditional Total War game.
The game was never meant to be a traditional total war.
8/10

When i first decided to play Total war battles: KINGDOM i thought it would just be a waste of my time like all the reviews said it would be... I saw one review that said it was good... and it was. This isn't just any ordinary game you can do so much with it.
You can...

-Fight with the armies
-Take over other sectors
-and so much more
Personnely my favorite of those is fighting with the armies. You can actually tell your men to move, when to charge, and archers who to shoot at. Changing the terrain is awesome as well. Most the time in games like this, you get a terrain and your stuck with it no way to change it. In this however, you can raise, lower, clear, and do even more with the terrain.
I highly reccomend this game to you, and remember i spent no money(not even within the game) to play. I hope this was helpful

reviewText:
Pay to win- Yeah
Have I played alot of pay to win and never pay a dime- Always.
This I dont mind sure slower but a time waster.

Speed of game- Slow
Like I said if you want something to do and dont mind clicking around and waiting or coming back to it then this game is not bad.

People complain about the 8 hour time it takes for certain things.(It can happen)
If you want to harvest wheat then do it individually and dont press the Harvest All or Fell All button which takes longer instead do it individually to minimize time.
I Like the fact that before bed I can click then harvest all and come back in the morning to see it ready for me.

Graphics are nice simular to the CIV games and Total war games.
Battles are different but whats wrong with that sometimes. If you play this game dont expect the same gameplay as the other Total War games.

I do think this game would be more enjoyable the farther I get and when it comes to mobile, I can play whenever and wherever I am at to waste time.

All in all not bad if you enjoy this kind of game 5/10 from me here. Again Its free to play so give it a try, I dont complain much when I get free things.

reviewText:
This game is nothing like all other total war games. And most gamers who like a series do not like to see that series do something different (like all shooter series). This game is more like tribal wars and settler online. If you like those games you will love this. Also the slow start will scare most gamers away, but like most building games you start with nothing and you will gain more when you play. Ones you have your second castle and 8 units (12 with militia) at your hands things will move faster and faster until you do not need to wait until your units are healed. By the time I'm writing this I have played the game for 4 days and I now have 4 castles and have 20 units and have not spend 1 gold. Gaining new lands is important and not impossible if you play smart. Also it takes time and practise to make the water your friend instead of your enemy (but then again I’m Dutch so building dams and cannels is in my blood)

Pro's:
Water: is vital for growing grass, tree’s, grain and fish
interactive map: you can built more things on this map than another free to play game out there. From canals to serval city's. (but you need to think ahead)
different seasons: these will change the map and how fights look but also create new problems and opportunities (like droughts in the summer are great to change the flow of the rivers)
You can build all things: No need to pay for stuff with gold/ real money to get all stuff in the game.
interactive fights: the fights are interactive can be won with pure skill
upgradable units: you gain experience, learn skills and you can build new and better weapons for your units
smart AI: the AI will use skills and will change formations of his units to match yours
different ways to gain gold: You can gain gold trough serval ways without paying for it with real money
Great graphics: best graphics for a game of this kind

cons:
Player vs player sucks: from cheating with buying all stuffs from unfair match making combine that with low reward and in sort multiplayer no fun.
slow start: If you are not able to gain new area’s fast (by fighting) you will have to few units

cons/pro's
No player raids: you cannot steal from others and they cannot steal from you
Raids :  sometimes a raider will appear and steal your resources if you not beat him in 24 hours (or bribe him)
Verdict: 8 Great game for those who are willing to spend

reviewText:
This game is good and fun despite what the naysayers with 30 minutes of playtime are saying.

To dispel the myth of Pay to Win...

-CRAFTING - This game is not Pay to Win. It is Pay to Go Faster like most F2P's.  You can craft everything so by definition, not pay to win.
-Many ways to obtain gold - Mine, wolves, tombs, daily tribute, markets, taverns, battle quests, challenges, conquering regions.
-Wait times - typical of Free to Plays.  Get used to it or move along to buyable games.


EDIT: ~6 hours in and I am just about at Lord level 15 (PVP unlocked at 15).  You unlock better units and coat of arms customizations too sometime after level 10.  There are a bunch of ways to earn gold for free too.  Could use a decrease in times here and there and some better explanations on certain aspects but I think it is a neat little game. Sorry not sorry.

EDIT 2: 10 hours in - I have multiple ways of getting gold now, but slowly.  I am level 19. Still liking the game.

EDIT 3: 20+ hours in - Level 27 Lord - a few cosmetics unlocked, 27 gold earned/received so far, 2 battles lost to the AI (which actually was smart in the last loss, dayum son).



Update .3 Review

Overall I'd say it is an improvement.  I played 53 battles on the first night of release.

+
Reduced times, mostly. 20 minutes >> 1 minute.  1.5 hours > 19 minutes, etc.
Gold 100% on daily login. Tombs now give gold
New things to mine (although not as intuitive). Silver, coal, gold, stone.
Adjacency bonuses - might still need tweaking but overall an improvement

-
Realm sized reduced. This is bad. We'll see how bad it is late game...
Fertile grass should be removed (wheat can't grow if it is 3 hexes away.)
Quarry has a massive range and can't be built next to each other. We're pressuring them on forums for change. Removing a lame prospect takes 12 hours which is absurd.
Gold prices for some units have been increased (others reduced).

reviewText:
Total war has taken their own twist on a different strategy game.

PROS

Battle gameplay better than all similar games

It doesnt take forever to construct. I really like this, games such as clash of clans may take hours for you to do upgrades, constructions, recruitments. This game however shortens it, making it a better experience

Resources dont run out quickly. I love this because in similar games, resources run out very quickly, in which you may have to wait hours to gain back. But total war battles makes it so resources are very well kept

You dont lose your army after battle. Yes you can keep your army, this makes the game even better, because you dont need to waste resources on another army

CONS

Feels very slow paced. It just doesnt excite you.

Battles should feel more like total war battles. I prefer it when you can move your army about, and not have your army auto moving. You should have more options to what you can do with your army.

This isnt really a PC game. It more of a mobile-style game, but oh well.

Turns. You know in these other total wars where you have turns, and after it recruits units and finishes constructions. I like that, however I suppose this isnt meant to be like it, I can accept that


Overall I enjoy the game.

reviewText:
First of all - addressing most of the negative reviews of this game: Do not treat this as a total war game. It may have the name Total War on it but it was never meant to be compared to the standard TW games. I started the game up expecting something similar to Tribal Wars and nothing more and that is exactly what this game has offered. A highly polished cross-platform casual game with fast (but fun) real-time battles.

As with all games of this genre there is an option to pay for gold to speed up your progress and recruit different (not overpowered, just a slightly different role) units. You can still earn gold in-game but unless you intend on playing this game for long periods of time in one go then gold is not neccesary. The Kingdom building is fantastic, you can terraform the land to your liking, build it how you like focusing either on your military to capture enemy (AI) settlements or on your economy to buy them out.

The PvP multiplayer aspect I haven't yet reached but I'm assuming so far it is for 1v1 army duels only so I can't comment on this.

You can customise your coat of arms with a variety of options which will then show up on the shields of your units, loading screens, and various other places.

Despite looking rather simple, the combat actually does have a lot of depth to it. In fact compared to any other casual-like game of this genre it has the most depth I have seen. There are 9 unit slots and you can build your army as you wish, individual-stat / ability progression per unit, special  ability-activated buffs you can earn from building churches and so on. There is more to the combat than this - try it! It seems mind-numbingly simple at the beginning but as the army sizes begin to grow and as you gain more abilities the game reveals more and more depth which was a very pleasant surprise.

Overall unless you buy gold with real money (you do get A LOT of gold for a small amount of money!) apart from at the beginning this is not a game that you can play for more than an hour at a time due to the nature of the game, but for playing half an hour or so every now and then it's brilliant. A fun, casual game. I highly recommend it!

reviewText:
I enjoy this game. This is a huge improvement on the previous battles game (shogun). The seasons system interests me greatly, the actual battles require a small amount of strategy and the resource management/base building is fun. When compared to other games of this genre it stands leagues ahead of them, combining the base building of mobile games with the battles of main series total war games.
To those comparing it to main series total war, don't, because it is completely different but still enjoyable as a free to play game. You CAN (but don't have to) pay for cosmetic items and to speed things up, but I find it is unnecessary and I will happily leave my blacksmiths forging while I go off and do something else.
I hope that the archery glitch will be fixed once it's out of beta.
Overall: fun and free.
