reviewText:
***written when in BETA with 7.7hrs played***

Upon seeing all the negative opinions for TWB:K I decided to take the time to give my thoughts.  I've been a fan of the TW franchise for quite sometime and don't usally play games such as this.  The game will have more appeal when it is cross-platform as the lack of hotkeys and dependence on a only using the mouse cursor to do everything becomes tedious.  I will continue playing this game despite the flaws I've seen in the BETA.  Oh, don't click the book in the top right it'll crash your game.


Pros:
f2p

beautiful graphics

runs on low end PCs

novel game concept

hilarious victory twist dance by spear men


Cons:
pay to progress

isn't made clear that gold is a cash currency (tutorial forces you to use gold to speed up production which can lead one to believe it's nessicary to do so and thus you waste most your gold at the start

all the blunders you make early on while learning how to play are permanent and will haunt you later

forced to use cursor and no hotkeys available

no blood

cannot see the resources required for a building you will soon unlock therefore planning ahead in that regard isn't possible

when you finally unlock the ability to change your flag it costs you way too much gold anyways

reviewText:
1. Yes it feels like a mobile game, so it's more of a casual pick up once in awhile and collect and fight etc. The fact you can play on all your devices makes it a good mobile game.

2. Yes a lot of units you have to pay in game gold, which is bought with out of game real money. But with that said, I haven't felt like I needed the extra strong units to win battles. And it feels like more of a pay to get ahead quicker rather than the pay to win like everyone claims. People really have a stupid view of what pay to win means.

3. I haven't encountered many bugs, and since it's autosave if the game were to crash you wouldn't lose any progress. Loads real quick also.

4. The battle is very submersive, you feel like a commander, commanding his troops on the battle field. You command when your units charge and who your bowmen fire upon. Do you shoot the men your horsemen are battling and risk killing some of your own?

5. Reminds me of a slow paced Ages of Empires. The graphics are nice and simple, but still pretty and colourful. It's a free game despite what the idiot masses would have you believe. It's not very pvp focused so you don't have to fight people who pay for units, etc., and get slaughtered. Just play it as a casual medieval times simulator.

Some things I would like to see implemented are, naming your towns, being able to move peasants to other towns, multiple profiles if I want to start a new game, more things happening graphically on the map i.e peasants walking around, trade carts moving from town to town, barracks has soldiers training, etc..

Total Wars games are usually $60 on release, the fact this game is free should tell you people that it's not going to be like a Total Wars game. It doesn't take 8 hours to farm crops, it takes 20 minutes, it takes 8 hours if you want to farm all at once. You should have to take an intelligence quiz before writing reviews, people are dumb.

reviewText:
I have not played a long time but this is first impressions
The Concept:
The Idea here is amazing you can play total war (admitedly scaled down) on the go and that is amazing
the fact you can play total war anywere (within reason) is a fantastic concept but it leaves the desktop
part of the game a little small compared to napoleon or shogun
The Gameplay:
Like i said before this is better on a mobile device for a quick 5 min burst of total war that is unaccesable
on PC The Battles are short and sharp but when you first start it is a bit long winded but overall it is a nice
idea like clash of clans and total war got squished into one.
The Good:
For a mobile game it is quite a ballenced easy to do game with the hex buillding and teraforming giving it
a burst of freshness to an alredy good game
The Bad:
Personaly i prefer having more of the RTS Factor having a unit of samuri or line infantry facing off against
a mass cavalry charge and gold Really Creative Asembaly Really it will just be another thing for pepole
with more money than sense to get better at a game and i hope this game does not end up like
Heroes and Genarals,Clash of Clans,Boom Beach and so meny other games of the P2W machanic.

Over all i give the Beta verson of total war battles:kingdom a 7/10
A fresh Take on a solid francise but the Gold Machanic and the fact it lets down PC Users knocked some
points of but i can not wait to see what happens next.

reviewText: I do not recommend this game for TW fans as it is a very different game than the rest of the TW series. Furthermore, this game is intended firstly to make money without any real marketing strategy. The basic gameplay is directly linked to the purchase of gold with real money. Otherwise the game is very slow. An example: my character is level 24 and I've done (almost) all possible developments after 20 hours of gaming. To go further, I need to have a castle level 2, which means 1500 stones and 1500 silver. If you don't speed up the game using gold (i.e. real money), you're making around 100 silver every 2 hours. Same with stones... So, just to get this damn castle to level 2, I have to wait around 30 hours!  The basic gameplay should be the same, gold or not. I have no problem with paying some money to the developers. Gold should allow to improve the gameplay, not to replace it. But in this game, if you don't use gold, there is no gameplay and the game is just a mock up version of old strategy games I played in the 80's on my first computers. The combat system is obviously made for tablets, not for PC. It is dull, with very little strategy and tactical choices (the biggest stick wins). The only interest I found in this game is the map and the way you can change it. There is a good idea there but it's a pity: no action (except economics and construction) is taken on the map... As if the devs had never played Stronghold or Civ. Strange!

reviewText:
Edit after over 2 months:

After over 2 MONTHS since my previous review, I figure that this game should be a lot better. Plenty of time to patch and improve things, right? WRONG! What do I see? The exact same, pay-to-win garbage.

I was hoping that this wouldn't happen, but it did. This game is cashing in on the (fairly) good name of Total War. I am incredibly dissapointed, and will likely not play again.


THE REVIEW BELOW IS OUTDATED:

As a fairly experienced Total War player, I can say that this game still has some of the spirit of the other  games in the franchise. Keep in mind, though, that I am recommending this as a free-to-play mobile game. Do not expect the same amount of depth as other Total War games.

Combat:
For a game of this type, the combat is amazingly good. For once, a mobile game allows you to have some control over your men (unlike letting them roam free" as in similar games).

Graphics:
So far
date: so good. I really like the overall atmosphere of the game. The lighting
hoursPlayed:
and objects all look crisp and good.

Pay-To-Win:
In the tutorial
voteText: battles were fast
helpfulPercent: building built in minutes. After the tutorial
votesHelpful:
it's a different story. I was quickly slammed with a 9 hour wait time.

Advice for CA:
Lower the building and clearing times in the beginning of the game. The jump is just too large after the tutorial. Also
votesTotal:
try to lower the building restrictions.

Should You Play?
I think that this game has enough potential to give a reason to play. Although

reviewText:
I was really excited to try this game as I have bought every total war game and really enjoy playing clash of clans.  I thought this would be perfect. It's a combination of both.

Unforntunity after playing I quickly realized it's like neither.

The game is setup for two tiers. Spending money in a free game should allow you to progress faster, but not give you units/upgrades that are much better then the competition. This creates two tiers of players. The ones that spend are much more powerful then the ones that don't. These means all the payers that don't leave as they can't compete. This reduces the amount of players and the competition level of the game so whats the point in paying then after all.

reviewText:
I think this game has a lot of potential. The game has a great opening and a good tutorial. I also like how the troops control during combat. It has a very smooth feeling and appears to be a rather good game considering it is 2 days old. There are a few issues however.

First is the teraforming issue. I like how you can change the altitude of the ground to help prevent floods or to create rivers. It is also cool that only certain buildings can be built in certain elevations. (Like how roads can only be built on medium height. it doesn't make sense for a road to go right over a mountain and then right back down) Now the issue I have is that when you want to raise something to be one higher than the area around the tile you can do that. BUT if you want to raise it 2 times you must raise all the other tiles around it. and if one of those tiles can't be raised you either have to raise all the tiles around it OR deal with the lower land and the inability to build something. So if I am at the top of the map and need to raise a piece of ground to medium for a road I have to first raise the tile I want to low, then the 3 below it to low then the nine below those to low. If you want to alter one tile you may have to raise 20 or 30 tiles. It is crazy. What should happen is that if I raise a tile from low to medium and the ground around it is very low it costs double and it just makes the ground look like a little hill on that tile.

The other issue is camera control. Just let me use WASD for camera movement. I don't to have to click and drag. It is alright for a mouse but what about anyone using a touch pad. It can take 30 seconds to a minute just to go from one side of the map to another just on the small starting one. Also, who likes a stagnate map? You are building a kingdom. Have people training in the barracks. Have a blacksmith hammering. people walking on the roads. If no one walks on them, what is the point?

The game itself is fun. Good combat aspects as well as animation and building design. I think for a new game it is doing alright but there is a lot of progress to be made.

reviewText:
I will actually give a review that isn't childish hate for hardwork. Or a fluff of fanboyism.
This game is free to play. So in reality they need to make some sort of profit off of it to make it worth their time and money, Keep this in mind when you begin playing it.
This is a game built to cater to total war fans AND tablet F2P fans. Keep this in mind when you begin playing it.
It is designed to let you play for a half hour to an hour. And then set it aside and do something else.
When you come back the next day you are rewarded with the things you did the previous day.
Hate this model or love it.
But this is a well built F2P game.
Looks beautiful, has a strategy battle system that is fun. But can become a little annoying because it is very rock, paper, scissors.
If you are willing to pay for your enjoyment, then you will be getting the accelerated experience. But it is no different then someone who doesnt. Just comes to you faster. The F2P idea is interesting. But I am not usually a fan. I love creative assembly and appreciate their hardwork on every game they have ever made. Because they do things no one else is willing to try.
These games are more rewarding if you are willing to be patient. But I will probably spend between 10 - 20 dollars on the game if it continues to pique my interest.
Don't turn away from the game based on the haters.
Give it a try, and actually give it some time. If its not your thing then remember that ITS FREEEEEEEE.
Thanks for reading, and hope you found this useful.
Have a good day!

reviewText:
So much hate on this game - I feel its misplaced.

OK - this is not a standard Total War PC game.  It is a mobile FTP kingdom building game with appointment mechanics.  Yes there are 8 hr cooldowns, but you're not supposed to sit and watch the cooldown.  You can use gold or you can come back later.  Its designed for short 5-10 min play sessions.  Obv this doesn't sit well on PC as its not what we're used to.  You can spend money to skip grind, but you don't gain utility value from spending so its not pay-to-win.  However if you spend as much as you'd be prepared to on a standard PC game, you will probably be able to compete with higher ranks, but only if you spend strategically.

I've played 9 hrs (FOR FREE) - it's got some interesting base building strategy, like balancing expansion with managing water levels.  You do have to wait to re-heal troops between fights which can mean you only have 1 fight per session, but if you overwhelm opposition you can get away with zero casualties and thus fight again straightaway.

Battles are more like a puzzle game than a traditional Total War fight, but still retains elements of setting up your formation to outwit opponent and making strategic moves mid game to counter act opponent's moves.

Biggest failing is that the game doesn't pit you against real opponents soon enough.  After 9 hrs I still haven't fought a real person - I assume this is coming!?!?

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
1.7 hours played, and 1.7 hours is all I need to make a decision.

Sadly, it seems that Creative Assembly has been in bed with SEGA too long to the point where everything becomes a micro transaction or a DLC cut from what should've been in the original game. This is a review for Kingdoms, so I digress.

Total War Battles: KINGDOM does not appear to be anything more than Creative Assembly's attempt at Game of War, or Clash of Clans (although this could viewed as an insult to these games). While their attempt is noble, these types of games are exclusive to mobile devices for a reason; I could play a much more fleshed out strategy game on my PC. If I want to play a game with busy work, it will be on my phone when I am waiting in between classes.

Creative Assembly revolutionized real time/turn based strategy gaming with the Total War franchise. My advice would be to stick to your niche and let the iOS devs stay in theirs.

reviewText:
People arent giving this game enough time, but I cant blame them.

Firstly this game starts stupidly simple and everything is basically locked and the only thing you really see are PAY MONEY TO COMPLETE THIS, and it makes you think 'uh no im definitely not gonna do that'

but as you progress (level 19 as of writing) things change everything starts to open up strategy become a huge factor with skills that add ALOT of depth to fights, this isnt your standard total war throw 5k troops at someone, it is actually skill based, which is weird but enjoyable.

Yes there are dumb things like PAY MONEY TO COMPLETE, but as you gain more castles and start getting gold for free, it changes everything.

I say give it a chance, you probably will enjoy it if youre into skill based rts, but it takes time to build your empire.

Edit: I have to change this review, after realizing how ludicrously long it will take to get decent units that you can simply pay to have, or the gold to resource exchange, it would take years for someone who is free to play to even COMPETE with someone pay 2 play, not only are the units locked, so are buffs for said units, which can be bought or crafted but expect to spend a quarter of a year gathering the necessary material or spend 2 dollars.

reviewText:
Listen, I think this game has a great idea behind it and I like the town building structure. Despite having a great base game... the combat system is pretty lame and not fun at all. I find myself not wanting to go to battle at all because it's
A) Extremely easy.
B) Tactics my grandma could devise ( she has no internet FYI)
C) Too small scale to wear the name Total War"
I really like the idea behind this game but it's not very nice to give players so many resources when they start out because you think it's going to be fun and you'll always have enough to do what you need but you find out pretty quick that it won't be like that for long. Please re-evaluate your approach to this game and then re-submit. Hopefully I can change my perspective later on but right now I just can't keep playing.

p.s bring us more TW games lel"

reviewText: Quite enjoying it though I wish it would let me restart cause there are quite a lot of lessons I have learned from playing the game, that I would like to restart and redo all over again. For example I built my second city on high ground then discovered I could not get a road to it, so I had to demolish it and rebuild.  Structure that I have learned earn me incoming like smithy, merchants, taverns etc. Built my tavern near the water and it got flooded :p, slums good for recruiting peasants but best built near water, mansions give more craftsmen, building farm in an area with only 3-4 available hexagons is a bad idea as this is where farm land is. Building soldiers no point in upgrading them at early stage rather just buy better soldiers, better soldiers are ultimately cheaper and will win e.g. upgrade soldiers gives 1 point in defence, as you unlock better units, that unit could end up offering an extra 25 points, each point you earn from experience is more expensive, so to earn 25 point equivalent is not going to happen, can also upgrade soldiers, armour, weapons etc.

reviewText:
Total War Battles obviously takes a lot of inspirations from all those build a castle and fight each other" browser games.
Unfortunately mostly in the "treadmill/paytowin" department. With maybe more substance in the "settlers/build" mode or more incentives to actually DO something between fights (even early on you will have to wait 8h to harvest something and between the . kinda nice - battles your troops will usually need 10-15 minutes to heal) this might work as a game.

Right now (12.4.2015 and after more than 2h of playing this game) i just have to say that the FUN is missing. And that is .... kinda bad
date: right?\nI might give it another try in a few weeks. But for the time beeing this is a nice looking but boring experience."

reviewText: Hats off Total War team, great concept. Been a fan of the Total War series since the original Medieval Total War. For those gamers out there that can't seem to wait 8 hours to harvest wheat, then I suggest taking your daily dosage for your ADD or ADHD or whatever it is they call it nowadays, sit down and figure out the value of x in the equation x^2 + y^2=1.  And possibly graph it on a Cartesian plane. (and btw x^2 means x squared. x times x, yes I know you weren't taught the x times table but tapped out at the 12. 12 X 12 = 144 booyah!) and when you finish that parabolic curve, guess what? Time to harvest wheat! Now why does the times table tap out at 12 cuz in the duodecimal system, 12 can be counted with one hand and 144 with two hands lol Again great work Total War Team, I can't wait for your games to get into the American Civil War. The PreModernized Warfare

reviewText:
So much hate on this game - I feel its misplaced.

OK - this is not a standard Total War PC game.  It is a mobile FTP kingdom building game with appointment mechanics.  Yes there are 8 hr cooldowns, but you're not supposed to sit and watch the cooldown.  You can use gold or you can come back later.  Its designed for short 5-10 min play sessions.  Obv this doesn't sit well on PC as its not what we're used to.  You can spend money to skip grind, but you don't gain utility value from spending so its not pay-to-win.  However if you spend as much as you'd be prepared to on a standard PC game, you will probably be able to compete with higher ranks, but only if you spend strategically.

I've played 9 hrs (FOR FREE) - it's got some interesting base building strategy, like balancing expansion with managing water levels.  You do have to wait to re-heal troops between fights which can mean you only have 1 fight per session, but if you overwhelm opposition you can get away with zero casualties and thus fight again straightaway.

Battles are more like a puzzle game than a traditional Total War fight, but still retains elements of setting up your formation to outwit opponent and making strategic moves mid game to counter act opponent's moves.

Biggest failing is that the game doesn't pit you against real opponents soon enough.  After 9 hrs I still haven't fought a real person - I assume this is coming!?!?
